results.description:
Hi everyone,

Our next meetup is planned for Wednesday January 27,[masked]am-1pm on the campus of Northeastern University - Behrakis Hall Rm 317. 

At this meetup, we'll be beginning a discussion on the process for commercializing a medical device. Some topics we'll discuss include:

• Regulatory Roadmap - US and EU markets

• Establishing a Quality Management System (QMS)

• Artifacts that can/cannot transfer from Research to Development

This is intended to be the first discussion on this topics. Additional topics will be discussed at future meetups. 

Looking forward to seeing you on Jan 27 @ 11am 317BH

Hope you all have a peaceful and joyous holiday.

Regards,

-Steve-

results.description:
DevOps is an industry buzzword but means different things to different people. In this session, we will discuss the IBM and Industry Point of View (POV). This is a collaborative session utilizing a whiteboard presentation as a forum for discussion for participants to learn and exchange ideas on DevOps approaches.

This is a face to face event held at the IBM Technical Exploration Center. Lunch will be provided.

Date:  Wednesday, January 27th, 2016

Time:  11:00 – 2:00 PM EST

Place:  IBM Technical Exploration Center

One Rogers Street, 2nd Floor, Cambridge MA 02142

Event registration required: 

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/devops-overview-and-adoption-strategies-lunch-and-learn-tickets-20621153425

Please join us or share with others on your team that are interested.  Please contact Tom Poovakad  ([masked]) with any questions you may have.

results.description:
Relationships.... with friends, lovers, peers, bosses, employees, and family, can be the blessing or the bane of our existence.  Join us to learn what Science, Philosophy, Spirituality have to say about creating and maintaining great relationships.

About Our Leader

Christine Duvivier, a Master of Positive Psychology, is a leader in the red-hot field of positive psychology. She has spent her life studying, applying and mentoring others to create the best relationships with colleagues, family, lovers and friends.  Drawing on experts in the fields of spirituality, leadership, happy couples, emotional intelligence, resilience and positive psychology, including Drs. George Vaillant, Stephen Covey, John Gottman, Daniel Goleman, Peter Drucker, Martin Seligman, Esther Hicks and others, Christine has distilled practices and frameworks that are easy to apply and begin improving relationships immediately.


She has mentored, facilitated, spoken and led positive change with thousands of individuals and groups worldwide, including Fortune 50 executives, individuals, families, and communities. Author of "What I'd Say if You Wouldn't Roll Your Eyes... love notes to my child," Christine mentors and facilitates other professionals-- including leaders, physicians, coaches, teachers and counselors-- using positive approaches to bring out the full potential in themselves and others. Clients say, "Christine helped me become the leader I am... get promoted.... turn problem staff to top performers... engage my team....  get people on board with new strategy and culture.... transform my relationships... see the best in me....feel energized."

She has personally experienced the power of positive change in her life and work, beginning her study and application at age 17.  While studying and working with the founders of positive psychology, she experienced the power of positive change when tragedy struck and she was catapulted into her own post-traumatic growth and resilience. Her groundbreaking research at UPenn identified paths to unleash hidden gifts and lead each of us to thrive in life.  www.christineduvivier.com

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
A warm welcome to new members of our meetup and a Happy New Year to all.

We are going to kick off 2016 with a great online event. This is a first event of its kind for our meetup. 

On January 27th one of our members, Richard Li from Datawire.io (and his team), is hosting a Microservices Practitioner Summit in San Francisco, CA. The event will feature presentations from engineers at Uber, Netflix, Yelp, and others. The talks will cover challenges and approaches in adopting microservices. You can find more details about the event at http://www.microservices.com/#event-details

The event will be streamed line on </a><a href="http://www.microservices.com/">http://www.microservices.com/. So go ahead and register.

Please let me know if you have any questions about the event. We will get back to our in-person meetup events starting in Feb/Mar.

Best,

Ajit Umrani.

These listening sessions will seek to solicit consumer, provider and community perspectives on a range of services provided by MCB, as well as allow for input and feedback on other topics of importance. MCB is inviting consumers, families, and all key stakeholders to attend; no rsvp required. MCB Commissioner Paul Saner will be on hand to hear your insights.

results.description:
Admission to the MFA (The Boston Museum of Fine Arts) is free after 4pm on Wednesdays!!

We get together in the Longwood Medical Area on Tuesday evenings for bilingual chat, but just a few blocks away is one of the world's finest art museums (and it also has a section on Sinology or China studies).

If you attend for free on Wednesday evenings, you'll be asked to make a contribution, but such gifts are purely optional.

This would be a host-free meetup where you 'just go' and bring friends, if you wish. I suggest that our group bring different small groups of bilinguals with China interest to the MFA, and make that a topic of discussion.

results.description:
Do you VEGETABLE-TARIANS want all the OTHER people (even if they have not committed to be vegetarians) to eat fresh produce?  Then help us - each Wednesday late afternoon - bag vegetables (and some fruit) for the neighbors in Mission Hill.  Usually there are also freshly-baked loaves of bread, also (baked that morning - Jessica's Bakery).

It's an assembly line, then take home a bag (or two) of produce for yourself. 

Bring your business cards, smartphone, or notepad, and prepare to exchange contact info with other volunteers you like.  Volunteers come from several sources (not merely this meetup or others:Craigslist, Pharmacy School, School of Public Health, etc.) 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
VOLUNTEERING for $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill 
Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street 
Mission Hill, Roxbury 
(between Brigham Circle and Roxbury Crossing T stops) 
Boston, MA 02120 - <2 blocks from Orange Line T Each Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm (indoors in bad weather)

We will be VOLUNTEERING for the weekly Wednesday late afternoon $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill.

When you volunteer, 
YOU will ALSO TAKE HOME one or two of those "$2 bags"! 
We've had 55 volunteers, and we've had 7.  Workloads vary!

Fair Foods provides a 20-22 bag of produce for the Mission Hill neighbors so they can eat like me - on produce. The neighbors only need to pay' $2 for the bag.

Volunteers unload the truck, set up 3 banquet tables, set up the food in order of desntiy (potatoes on bottom - tomatoes and bananas and berries and kale on top), then fill each bag (and 'stack' them upright by one another - for the 'paying neighbors' to pick up (for $2). 

Some arrive as early as 3:30 pm (you don't NEED to do that, but you're welcome to do so; OUR meetup's attendees - it's posted on 6 meetups - are often there early, and you can chat).


We (MOST of us) arrive around 4 pm (maybe as late as 4:30 pm) and work until 6 pm or so (can leave as early as 5:30 pm if we've finished).

In the FRONT of the Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street (between the Brigham Circle T stop - GREEN E-Line - and the Roxbury Crossing Orange Line T stop), behind the wrought iron fence.

Wear comfortable clothing that allows you to move flexibly and to actually work, lifting heavy bags of food. 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Tobin Community Center 
1481 Tremont Street, Boston, MA

THERE IS NO PARKING - IT'S BEST FOR THOSE WHO LIVE IN BOSTON AND TRAVEL IN ON THE MBTA

THERE IS NO PARKING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

Use the T - #66 bus comes by - E-Line or Orange Line

Every Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Bring friends!  Forward the invitation to others!

Invite FRIENDS through the Facebook, LinkedIn, and Twitter 'share' 
buttons
http://www.yelp.com/events/boston-volunteering-for-2-bag-of-produce-in-mission-hill-each-wednesday-afternoon-from-4-6-pm-at-tobin-community-center

Looking for an ARTIST to help VISUALLY REPRESENT this vegetable outreach effort.
TALK with us FIRST !!
Looking for Gifted Marketers to
(i) conceptualize the WHY of low cost vegetable distribution! and
(ii) the desirability of TAKING the low cost vegetables !!

LOGISTICAL CHALLENGE IS TO GET LOW COST VEGETABLES to the REFRIGERATORS of LOCAL RESIDENTS !!!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Vegan Cooking classes or Vegan Cooking Ideas

What Can You Do With Your $2 Bag?

Portion Control

Bake...Don't Fry!

Roasted Veggie Stackers

No-Guilt Banana Ice Cream

Avocados!!!

Salad with Chipotle Hummus

Simple Cilantro Chutney

More $2 bags of Produce!

Drink your greens!

Question:
This sounds like a great deal, but is it meant for those in need, as is the case with food banks?

Answer:
No qualifications - no limitsWe have way more than AMPLE food for any intended audiences, and the operation is bettered if MORE people take the food than if FEWER take the food.

Therefore, there is NO QUALIFICATION (no test of need) and no limit to how much you can cart off (just pay $2/bag and $1/loaf of bread).  That's why I post it on a meetup like this.
Make us busy - very busy.

results.description:
DATE: Wednesday, January 27, 2016

TIME: Registration opens up at 6:30pm | Screening begins at 7:00pm LOCATION: Kendall Square Cinema | 355 Binney St. | Cambridge, MA


Join GlobeDocs for a special screening of An Open Secret, a disturbing documentary about the sexual abuse of children in Hollywood. Directed by Oscar®-nominated director Amy Berg, An Open Secret follows the lives of five boys who came to Hollywood with dreams of becoming actors but were instead funneled towards sexual predators without any oversight or regard for their safety. Following the screening there will be a Q&A with the films Producer, Matt Valentinas, moderated by Boston Globe Movies Editor Janice Page.


Want to support the future of documentary filmmaking in Boston? Please consider making a voluntary donation to the Boston Globe Documentary Film Fund. This fund, a part of the Boston Globe Foundation, a nonprofit 501(c)(3), will be used to give an annual award to a documentary filmmaker to continue producing high-quality work that engages and enlightens the public. Suggested levels: $0 - I just want to see a good movie
$5 - I'm a starving artist myself but want to contribute something
$10 - Lights, camera, action!
$20 - I want to help build the future of documentary filmmaking in Boston

SPACE IS LIMITED. YOU CAN REGISTER 2 PEOPLE FOR THIS EVENT.

Registrations will be accepted in the order they are received and based on availability.

Seating will be first come first served and is not guarenteed. *By registering for this event you will be automatically subscribed to GlobeDocs and Society of Grownups relevant e-newsletters. You may unsubscribe at any time.
results.name: An Open Secret    documentary    1-27  Wed.     Kendall Sq.  7 PM

results.description:
Who should join: Beginners to Advanced speakers interested in learning how to improve their public speaking for fun or professionally.  Reduce your fear and increase your confidence.


Why  members should join: Learn the basics of public speaking, challenge your current skills to be a professional speaker or just to have fun & meet interesting people.  You will also be challenged to give more challenging types of speeches such as ice breakers, humorous and inspirational speeches.

What members can expect out of the group: We have a fast paced 1 hour meeting packed with 2 prepared speeches from members as well as Table Topics where anyone is invited to speak on a suggested topic for 1-2 minutes to hone their ability to speak off the cuff.


You can also join our mentorship program and be assigned an advanced speaker who will guide you to improving your skills.

Lead meetings and presentations at work, begin your path to being a better teacher or professional paid public speaker or simply be a better storyteller.

Tuesday 12pm meeting for members and guests. Please visit for free! 

All are welcome.

Kevin Vandecar from the Autodesk Developer Network, is going to present various tools available now to add 3D content to web apps including Autodesk View and Data API with an AngularJS-based front-end. Kevin will also talk the group through a Quick Start Guide of how to implement your own 3D model on the Web using Client and optional Server side View and Data API’s. 

Speaker Bio: 
Kevin Vandecar is a principal developer consulting engineer and also the manager for the Media & Entertainment Autodesk Developer Network Workgroup. His current specialty is 3ds Max software customization and programming areas. Within the past few years, he has also been polishing his web development skills and exploring areas in WebGL and Three.js, along with the new Autodesk Forge platform.

7pm - Talk + questions

Agenda

6:30-7:15pm: Aria's talk on internationalization

7:15-7:45pm: Breakout sessions (see more info below)

7:45-8pm: Regroup and debrief

Presenter


Aria Stewart (https://twitter.com/aredridel) is the architect of the npm web site and formerly of the kraken team at paypal, where she worked on i18n components for the Kraken framework.

Topic


A roll-up-your-sleeves how-to on how to internationalize applications of all sorts, then how to work on getting translations, strategies for maintaining the mountain of derivative content, and how not to do the things that will make all of that more complicated.

We’ll go into

• localization as accessibility

• command line applications


• web applications


• native applications


• content databases


• translation worflows


• quirks of languages that surprise developers

Breakout sessions

In addition to the main talk, there will be smaller breakout sessions where people could pick a topic based on interest and have more in-depth conversations with other like-minded people.

For this event, some preliminary topics are (they could change based on interest)

- Internationalization & localization

- Extensibility and customizations

- Front-end tooling (grunt, gulp, npm etc.)

results.description:
Simultaneous Localization And Mapping (SLAM) has progressed far beyond the theoretic interest of the last decade. It's found its way into commercial products (iRobot) and object recognition (CSAIL). Hear all about it from two experts in this field!

Rough agenda: 

6 - 6:30: Networking and Pizza


6:30 - 7:20: Two Speakers

   (1) Wes Huang, iRobot: Visual SLAM on the Roomba 980

iRobot's latest robotic vacuum cleaner, the Roomba 980, is the first Roomba to have a camera which it uses to navigate around a house. Its visual navigation capability supports many current and future features on the Roomba. I'll describe the Visual SLAM system that runs on the robot and conclude with a live demo.

   (2) Sudeep Pillai, MIT CSAIL: Towards SLAM-Aware Scene Understanding

Robots need to be able to navigate through environments, perform manipulation tasks, and avoid obstacles, all while having a strong spatial and semantic understanding of its immediate environment. My research focuses on leveraging SLAM-aware robots to better inform scene semantics including object recognition. I'll discuss a recent result in SLAM-supported object recognition that improves monocular object recognition performance over existing frame-based techniques. Inherent to the spatial and semantic understanding is the choice of map representation. I'll discuss new map representations in the context of visual SLAM, and shall show some very recent results of an application involving high-speed map reconstructions using stereo cameras. Finally, I'll motivate the necessity for self-supervised SLAM-aware robots that are capable of learning the representation of an environment while persistently experiencing and navigating through.


7:20 - 7:30: 1 min pitches from audience. Need help? Looking for a job? Let us know. 

7:30: Raffle for a Roomba!

Rest of the evening: more networking.

Location/Parking: the Microsoft NERD center is a short walk from the Kendall Sq. T stop, located adjacent to the Charles River. There's usually street-parking to be found on side streets (such as Ames St.). There's also a garage in the NERD center, $10 flat fee after 4pm. Please remember to bring your ID to get into the NERD center.
results.name: New Directions for SLAM

Also, two announcements:

• I'm having a baby soon (though not before Wednesday, I hope), so I'll be looking for other people who might want to lead discussions in the near future. You don't have to host or feed people; you could facilitate discussion with people who meet up in a cafe or similar. Please let me know if this is something you'd be interested in doing! 

I also generally want to have more variety in types of meetups; I expect we will continue doing dinners about once a month, but it would be good to have other types as well (meeting for coffee; meeting at different times of week or day; social meetups without discussion being a particular goal). I'd love to hear what most interests you.

Julia (and Jeff)

One of the least visible parts of edX's work is doing research about what works in online education. Through our online offerings, and in partnership with on-campus courses at our partners, we investigate better ways to teach online.

Piotr Mitros, edX Chief Scientist; and Nina Huntemann, edX Director of Academics and Research; will discuss the research landscape around edX. How is edX being used as a research platform? What are the frameworks available, and what are we learning from it?  What have we already found out about online learning, and what are the hot questions people are investigating?


Bring your research ideas and curiosity!

Pizza will be provided. :)

{Join the newest Heartbeat Salon location, in Melrose MA, as we experience a film that will help you appreciate ... and utilize... that beautiful treasure you keep in your chest.


Explore the astonishing power and intelligence of your heart with friends and neighbors in the north-east corner of Boston, and with inspiring and influential icons of our age, including Paulo Coelho, Maya Angelou, Deepak Chopra, Isabel Allende, and Eckhart Tolle. - DP}


Tonight we will ...

Take time to discover the Power of our hearts.  Your heart generates the strongest electromagnetic field in your body. 

https://youtu.be/jobk3Usi73k

Since the beginning of recorded history, the great teachers of the world's spiritual traditions have described the heart as the source of true power and understanding.  This film highlights ideas from current spiritual thinkers, writers, and scientists. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oYfzjBV0vR4

Come join us for light snacks and a discussion following the screening about what "living more in our heart" might be all about.  

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QCuUwQMLsAQ

What to prepare and think about before coming:

When in your life did you rely on your heart as your guide?

What were the results a) short term b) long term

Have you ever experienced your heart's wisdom and seen manifestation?

Where in your life do you resist connecting with or listening to your heart?

Our Leader This Evening is Heather Josephson

Heather Josephson was educated in the field of Educational Psychology, and worked for many years as a school psychologist.  She decided to leave the profession and launch enrichment programming for children through the public schools.  In 2009 she created Education Stations and Campus KIDS programming, and has acted as the director for the past 7 years.  

Heather is passionate about helping people live healthy and happy lives.  Her current project is a small business focused on community enrichment, called Zoom Zone.  She is excited to be a part of the HBS, to learn and grow with others on their journeys.

Our Host This Evening is Olga Privina


https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/-TbuN1_DS26k/VhGgh9yNEUI/AAAAAAAAAT0/5G-hh23Wk1Q/w426-h425/DSCF0426.JPG

Olga Privina is a certified consulting hypnotist, the manager at the newly opened child and adult enrichment center, Zoom Zone, and the host of the our most recent HeartBeat Salon in Melrose.

Because Olga is a spiritual person and lives from the heart, she very excited to host this wonderful movie about the power of the heart. She believes in love, energy and positive intention. 

There are many ways to create a better life for yourself, to help and support others and to explore your different options. She is very happy to be a part of this group of like minded people.

The Melrose Zoom Zone is a newly opened enrichment center for adults and children. It offers classes and activities throughout the month.

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex. Here is a map of the area.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Please come out and join us for a pleasant evening of competitive party bridge in  Newton Centre.  Wednesday night bridge here has been a multi-year Metrowest tradition; it is a nice quiet spot with a fireplace, good food, ample table space.  The more the merrier, so long as you know how to play bridge and love it.

This is officially canceled unless 5 players sign up by 5pm. We can still play with four if we re-confirm. Check this space at 5pm if quorum questions exist. Out of courtesy, please do not sign up casually, nor cancel out on the day of event except in emergencies.

You must know Contract Bridge rules and basic bidding to play this week. No formal training is to be offered, but this is a social, casual event. To assist novices, bidding advice and meanings will be openly discussed on any player's request.

ACBL Yellow Card is our group-standard bidding system; a novice should please take time to study all basic openings and responses shown above in yellow, plus standard Jacoby Transfer and Stayman responses to NT openings. We will expect a verbal alert on deviations an expert may make to these most-common conventions.
results.name: A Newton Center Bridge Party

'Intro to Boston' is a series of events that highlight communities of thinkers and changemakers throughout the city of Boston. 

Each event will give a deep dive into a respective space. Through panel discussions and 1x1s with professionals in these communities you will learn all the ins and outs to break into a new industry.


About the Panelist

Jessica Muise

Member Services Manager,
Artisan's Asylum

Jessica Muise is an arts advocate, dance artist and educator. As Member Services Manager at Artisan's Asylum, she is dedicated to helping people make what they imagine. 

She has always been drawn to creation as pedagogy which, as an act of transformation, helps us better understand each other and ourselves. She has a B.A. from New York University in transformative pedagogy and has a graduate certificate in dance education from the University of KwaZulu-Natal in Durban, South Africa. 

An arts administration junkie, she has led development and infrastructure projects for Green Street Studios, the Boston Community Network Project, the Permaculture Institute of the Northeast, and National Choreography Month amongst others. 

Her dance company, Intimations Dance, has presented been at the Boston Contemporary Dance Festival, First Night Boston, the Cambridge River Festival, Somerville’s ArtBeat and has been awarded the GreenWorks Residency and aMaSSiT mentoring lab at the Dance Complex. 

She has given talks and workshops on the arts and permaculture design for various organizations including KZNArts Link, Massachusetts College of Art & Design, TEDx NYU, Newton Community Education, Collective Motion Arts and MovingTarget Boston. Her work at Artisan’s Asylum focuses on programming, community development and volunteer management.


In Partnership With:


The Workbar Network is an interconnected community of coworking spaces in Boston, Cambridge, and across New England. Workbar membership includes access to inspiring workspace, local business resources, and a variety of weekly workshops and events. Join one of Workbar’s dynamic Hub locations, collaborate with leaders in your industry at one of our Centers of Excellence, or share dedicated space with a local company that fits your culture and workstyle.

Come join us for a midweek climb!


All levels are welcome! If you are new to climbing, there is a belay class at 7 PM. Here is the link to sign up: www.centralrockgym.com/bookeo.php?s=watertown 

I will happily belay those who have not climbed before up until 7 PM, but then it's really important to know how to belay and to take the belay test that starts at 7 PM. You can rejoin the group after taking the belay test.

For those of you who already know how to belay, no need to take the class, you just need to pass this gym's belay test when you arrive.

The price is as follows:

Membership: $89/month

Adult Day Pass: $22 

Gear (shoes, harness, belay device): $8 ($5 for members)

Belay class: $15 (free for members)

Belay test: Free

We will meet at the cluster of cubbies on the first floor at 6:30 PM, greet each other, make sure everyone has a group or person to climb with then head off to climb. I'm looking into whether there is a place nearby to grab a bite or drink at the end of the night. If you have a place in mind, please let me know.

I'll send a message letting you know what color shirt and pants I am wearing incase you arrive late and want to search for us. I will also swing by the cubbies every 15 minutes until everyone who signed up has arrived. So, if you are not able to make it or are running late, PLEASE COMMUNICATE on this event's chat or by contacting my cell-phone, which I will send out once you are confirmed for the event.

Hope you can make it! I'm looking forward to meeting more climbers in the area.

~Avery~

Special Fathom Features: Enjoy unique access to the masters of the Italian Renaissance and an inside look into the renowned the Uffizi Gallery.

Fathom Events, SpectiCast, and Nexo Digital are inviting audiences to enjoy an intimate tour of the world famous Uffizi Gallery when Florence and the Uffizi Gallery comes to select cinemas nationwide on Wednesday, January 27.

Florence and the Uffizi Gallery is a multi-dimensional journey through the city that was once the cradle of the Italian Renaissance. Get an exclusive tour through the most beautiful and representative works of art of the period from Michelangelo and Brunelleschi, to Leonardo and Botticelli, with a detailed central chapter dedicated to the very treasure house containing their masterpieces: the Uffizi Gallery.

This special one-night event also includes the breathtaking “Adoration of the Magi” by Leonardo Da Vinci, which, after several years of restoration, will be brought back to life and unveiled in this worldwide exclusive premiere on the big screen.

Don’t miss your chance to see the works of the giants of modern art, larger-than-life on the big screen for only one night!

They're limiting the showing of this movie.  It's not in Danvers but in Revere, another large and confusing complex.  They do have a bar there, and I suggest we meet just outside the door to the bar.  Then we can buy tickets together.  Tickets are $16. 

If any of this changes your plans, please change your RSVP.

RSVP here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/how-to-get-a-job-as-a-product-manager-tickets-20704449566

Making a career switch can be a thrilling and daunting task for many. Whether you are just beginning to think about taking the leap or you're in the middle of the process, it is easy to get overwhelmed. How do you know when to leave your current role and how do you best position yourself for your next?

What you will learn: 

• Get an overview of the curriculum and course objectives

• Meet the instructor and hear about his professional experience

• Discuss Frequently Asked Questions • Have the opportunity to ask any & all additional questions

Who is this workshop for: 

- Software engineers who want to transition to Product Management 

- MBAs with a finance/consulting background who want to work in high-tech companies as a Product Manager

- Project Managers, Marketers, Designers who are seeking for new opportunities in Product Management 

Timeline:

6:30pm - 8:30pm : Presentation and Q&A

Meet the speaker: Carlos González de Villaumbrosia

Carlos is CEO at Product School. He has eight years of experience building teams and digital products on 3 Continents. He is a three times company Co-founder. Before Product School, he was the Lead Instructor of Product Management at General Assembly and Co-founder and CEO of Floqq (invested by 500Startups), the biggest marketplace for online video courses in Latin America.

Sponsor:

Product School is an education company that offers Product Management courses in San Francisco, Silicon Valley, Los Angeles, New York and Boston.

Our instructors are professionals with over 5 years of real-world product management experience working at renowned tech Companies like Google and LinkedIn, and other technology startups. Our students are professionals with over 3 years of experience in technology, business or design roles.

results.description:
Susan Rose will be leading this meditation. The name of the meditation is Being Aware of Being Loved.  It is a variation of a lovingkindness meditation that Susan created herself.   Our event start time is 6:45pm.  But please arrive early to settle in.  

Our schedule: 
6:30pm -  It's great to arrive early to ask questions and find a good seat.  We have chitchat time starting around 6:30. Come hang out with us and feel free to peruse the store. 
6:45pm - Class starts. 
Please note: We lock the door at 7pm.  At 7pm, you are already 15 minutes late for class, so please do not disturb the class by trying to enter or knocking.  
8:00pm - Class ends. 

What happens during class: 
   The 75 minutes that we spend together will include: 
           1) discussion about meditation and mindfulness 
           2) instructions on how to meditate 
           3) experience the Being Aware of Being Loved meditation 
The length of the meditation itself will probably be about 15 to 25 minutes long. No previous experience is required; the meditation will be easy for beginners to understand. 

More info: 
Our website has more information about the history of our Community Meditation Nights.  http://www.mindfulboston.com/classes/#/community-meditation-nights/

What to bring: 
It's fine to just show up as you are.  
Yet, please be aware that (as you can see in the pictures) most of us do sit on the floor.  Some folks choose to bring their own pillow for sitting on the floor, but there are no requirements to bring anything. 
If you require a chair for health reasons, make sure to RSVP and write "please reserve a chair for me" in the comments section below. We have about seven chairs, and typically 20 to 30 people participate.
results.name: Community Meditation Night- Being Aware of Being Loved

More Great Speeches: Wed, Jan 27.  - Don't let your speaking abilities hold you back this year.

Did you ever imagine speaking to a group could be fun?

Our Meet-ups continue to win rave reviews from first-time guests. They enjoyed the simple exercises and learned useful techniques for connecting with an audience.

Our meet-ups are fast-paced and entertaining. Nobody feels intimidated. Come experience it for yourself: You'll get to listen to prepared speeches and learn simple yet effective speaking tips.


You are welcome to participate in our two-minute impromptu speaking exercises, but certainly not required. We do have a 30-second “Round Robin” that everyone participates in (it’s fun and easy), and you’ll probably be asked to introduce yourself [talk very briefly about an interest, or what brought you there]. Pretty basic, no surprises.  The only requirement is to enjoy yourself and get a sense of how the meet-ups run. [They start promptly at 6:50, so please arrive by or before 6:45. They end by 8:30 pm.]


Mark Your Calendar - Our Next Meet-Ups:

results.description:
Hey everyone & Happy 2016! 

This January meetup is inspired by the Hack night we had last October. 

** We will have a google hangouts open during the meeting, please RSVP if you want the link emailed to you. 


For those of you who weren’t there, there were about 20 of us sitting around a round table brainstorming different ideas on events and things we want to do for the club. It was extremely helpful to get instant feedback on ideas and hear new ones we hadn’t thought of. 

We’re shaking things up this year with the Boston WWC chapter and we want to figure out what our niche is in the women in tech Boston scene. 


Do we want to continue have low-key hack nights monthly?
Do we want to set up some volunteer opportunities to work with young girls considering tech?
Do we want more social events?
Do we want to have study groups and monthly assignments so that we can learn together?
Do we want to work with the other women in tech meetup groups and plan big events?
Does anyone want opportunities to become more involved in the club and take on more responsibility? 

We have a pretty large user base and lots of great connections in the community, so the potential is pretty limitless. 

The event space we’re going to be at is huge and there are tons of private rooms as well. So if you are just looking for a quiet place to work by yourself or with a group of people, and you don’t want to participate in brainstorming that is 100% welcome as well. 

As always, WWCode events are intended for ALL women (trans/cis), trans men, and genderqueer folks who are interested in attending. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly and committed to matters of social justice as an organization. Select events may be open to the general public, which will be clearly noted in event descriptions. If you have any questions (or identify differently and want to attend), please message the Directors of this Network.
results.name: Hack Night / Brainstorming Session

http://commonwealthherbs.com/winter-skin-care-lotion-making-class/

results.description:
Cold wind outside, forced hot air inside – winter in New England can dry you out both coming and going. Dry lips, chapped hands, and cracked skin are uncomfortable and persistent. Commercial moisturizers often contain alcohol and can irritate the very skin they’re supposed to heal. Fortunately, it’s simple enough to make your own herbal skin lotion – once you learn how you’ll never go back!

Learn a skin cream recipe to protect and nourish cold-chapped skin. Lotion recipes are based on the chemistry of creating an emulsion, a blend of oil and water soluble ingredients that requires the right ratios and some patience to achieve properly.

This is a hands-on class, no experience required! We’ll discuss how best to select herbs for lotion making, and we’ll perform a demonstration of the emulsifying process along with some tips for troubleshooting runny products.

Wednesday, January 27th, 2016
7:00pm – 9:00pm
25 St. Mary’s Court, Brookline

http://commonwealthherbs.com/winter-skin-care-lotion-making-class/
results.name: Herbal Lotions for Dry Winter Skin

results.description:
Psychiatric Diagnoses: How Useful Are They?

The labels that are assigned to people who are typically considered as having mental illness are often used out of convenience. They can be shorthand that attempts to describe inner states and their corresponding outward behaviors; they are helpful in decision-making when clinicians decide to prescribe medications to treat these conditions; and they can also be important in non-clinical applications, where insurance may or may not cover treatment, or in the courtroom where there needs to be a translation so that judges and lawyers will be able to join the conversation.

There are many considerations, however, that demonstrate the limitations inherent with the use of formal diagnostic categories, as well as with the everyday expressions that many of us use. The emerging peer movement seeks to substitute a non-stigmatic approach to re-identify those who have been labeled with the more conventional, recognizable descriptive terms—both formal and informal. Ultimately, a person is not the label he or she caries, and we can begin to confuse the person with the diagnosis if we are not careful. In this brief piece I will use some of my personal experiences to illustrate some inconsistencies and limitations of psychiatric diagnoses.

Claude Spiro


During the discussion co-host Robin will address disorders such as Anxiety & Depression, Autism, ADD, Eating Disorders, PTSD, Schizophrenia, and SAD, and offer evidence that:

• Most of the conventional mental diagnoses are tools of big pharma and big medicine for making huge profits selling life-long drugs that do more harm than good

• Most cases of these mental illnesses are caused by toxics, nutritional deficits, poverty, chronic stress, social deficits, and lack of understanding of natural healing and human instincts

• Other mental illnesses that are more common and dangerous are not on the list and are rarely discussed, including tribal arrogance, mindless conformity, belief in myths, confirmation bias, and hyperconservatism
results.name: Talk on Psychiatric Diagnoses by Claude Spiro (rescheduled to Jan. 27)

results.description:
(Please note our new RSVP policy below.) 


We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, most of which are Euro style games of medium complexity.  Games often last 90 minutes or more and involve juggling a lot of rules and factors in your head, to decide what to do.  However, there's also plenty of laughter and friendship involved.  If that sounds up your alley, we hope you'll join us. 

Our weekly meetup is in a TERRIFIC space for games steps from the Kendall Square T, with easy parking, and lots of room to spread out in.  Full directions are below.  The building door does get locked in the evening, but there is plenty of foot traffic in and out.  If you expect to arrive later than 8:30, send Tucker a message earlier in the day, and we'll make sure someone is there to let you in.

Our meetups happen once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 pm onwards.  Our group has been running since 2007, and we have a large crowd of regulars as well as new members each week.

1. Due to finite space, you must RSVP to attend.

2. Please be considerate of others -- only RSVP if you are likely to attend.  Likewise, If you need to cancel your RSVP, please do so at least 24 hours before the event.  This allows enough notice for someone else to use your spot.

3. Please save loud and/or big games (like those with real-time arguing) for after 9:30, when the room is less full.  This allows us to accommodate more people, and play a greater variety of games.

We play whatever people bring, which typically includes a lot of Euros.  Here's a "tip of the iceberg" look at a few games that have been popular lately:

7 Wonders, Terra Mystica, Race for the Galaxy, Splendor, One Night Werewolf, Le Havre, Hansa Teutonica, Machi Koro, Concordia, Super Big Boggle

As you can see, there is some real variety.  A few of our regular attendees bring about 20-30 games between them, so there's always a lot to choose from.  But if you have a game you like, just bring it with you!

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

Finally, a note about Settlers of Catan, Carcassonne, and Ticket to Ride.  These are traditional "gateway games" that many people play when they first discover Euros.  Although you will occasionally find those games at our meetups, many of us have played them to death and have become more interested in games with a little more complexity to them.

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, proceed behind the T entrance (perpendicular to Main Street).  Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs or elevator straight up. Proceed straight ahead (perpendicular to Main Street). Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it.
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south.
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

Once you enter, Room 119 is just past the stairs on the right. There is a suggested donation of $1.00 that goes towards site fees and party supplies.  (When we have a raffle, you will also receive an extra raffle ticket as thanks for donating.)

Feel free to email with any questions -- we hope to see you at a meetup soon.

OTHER POLICY DETAILS:

If you would like to come but there are no spots, consider attending our alternative "Light Game Night" a few steps away at Cosi Cafe.  You can also sign up as "wants a spot" and receive emails from meetup if a spot opens up.

We know everyone has emergencies.  But consistent, inconsiderate use of RSVPs -- which includes being a "no show", cancelling in the last 24 hours, or constantly cancelling RSVPs -- will lead to being removed from the group.  Sorry, we still like you, it's just not fair to everyone else!

If you use a "+1" spot, you are responsible for all of the above for your +1.  Since you are using two spots, it is extra important that you are considerate about it.

NEW MEMBERS: Welcome!  We look forward to meeting you.  If you want to bring a friend, please have them sign up with their own account rather than using a +1.  Unfortunately, we've gotten a lot of no-show +1's from first time attendees, so we don't accept those anymore.  Sorry!
results.how_to_find_us: Walk a quarter of a block from the Kendall T, in the opposite direction from the Marriott Plaza. We're in the big building on your right (across from the parking lot). When you enter, our room is just across the foyer and on your right.
results.name: Wednesday Game Night

results.description:
Join the Boston Austrian Economics Group as we embark upon Chapter 15: The Market, of the Austrian classic; "Human Action: A Treatise on Economics," by Ludwig von Mises. The group will discuss the weekly readings and questions.

Please note that the readings are not required to attend our meeting, but are recommended. As always, anyone interested in economics is welcome.

Tony C's Sports Bar and Grill has plenty of parking and is accessible via the Orange Line "Assembly" stop. Our group meets in the private room at the back of the restaurant, the reservation is under Austrian Economics Group.

Please feel free to call Natalya @[masked], with any questions.


READING: 

Part 4, Chapter 15: The Market 

QUESTIONS: 


1) What are the main characteristics of the market economy, and what is meant by the "market is a process?"

2) What are the defnitions of capital, capital consumption, and saving?


3) What is the notion of real capital, and why is it nonsensical?

4) Who determines what is produced, and what is the role of the entrepeneur in the market?

5) What is the difference between biological competition and social competition?

6) How are the terms liberty and freedom related to the state and the market economy?

7) Is it necessary to guarantee equality of income in order to obtain freedom?

8) What role do the complementary factors of production and the final product play for entrepreneurial profit? 

9) What is the ultimate source from which entrepreneurial profits and losses are derived?

10) Why can't the surplus of the total sum of entrepreneurial profits exhaust the total increase in wealth by economic progress? 

11) Why is the socialist concept of "unearned income" fallacious?

12) Why is it false to assume that people with limited resources are not able to achieve great wealth, or be the next big innovative entrepreneur?
results.how_to_find_us: Our group meets in the private room at the back of the restaurant, the reservation is under Austrian Economics Group.
results.name: THE MARKET

results.description:
This is our brand new auxiliary meetup event.  This is a great opportunity to socialize and play games in a relaxed environment -- and best of all, there's no cap on attendance.

We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, but the games at this particular event are going to be on the smaller side -- because those are often the games that work best in a cafe setting.

Our main meetup requires RSVPs due to heavy popularity and finite space.  This event runs simultaneously, two buildings away.  RSVPs are NOT required for this event.  RSVPs are still appreciated so the event hosts know how many people to expect, but you don't need to update them and can come even if you don't RSVP.

This event takes place once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 - 9:30 or 10.  Cosi closes at 10, but after 9:30, you are welcome to come and join the regular meetup at that point, no RSVP required.

Cosi Cafe has graciously allowed us to use their back seating area every week.  You are not required to buy anything from them, but their food is honestly pretty good, so please take advantage of them if you are hungry for dinner, soft drinks, or snacks.

We play whatever people bring, but you don't have to bring anything -- the hosts will always have a bag of games with them!  Some games that you might expect to see here include:

Red 7, Love Letter, Codenames, Pictomania, The Resistance, Avalon, One Night Ultimate Werewolf, Bang!, Glory to Rome, Innovation, Mottainai, Chrononaughts, Time Lines, Tash-Kalar

If you're looking for longer or larger Euros (like 7 Wonders, Puerto Rico, or Terra Mystica), check out our regular "Game Night" meetup.

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, turn left and walk about 20 feet to Cosi.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs up, then up again towards the busy street, which is Main Street.  Turn left and walk about 20 feet to Cosi.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it. 
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) One side of the parking lot has a bunch of buildings with a handicapped ramp leading into it.  Go up the ramp, through the walkway, and Cosi will be right next to you when you come out.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south. 
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) One side of the parking lot has a bunch of buildings with a handicapped ramp leading into it.  Go up the ramp, through the walkway, and Cosi will be right next to you when you come out.

results.description:
Welcome to the weekly BKBS Wednesday meet up. Please join us at 7:00 PM by the 3rd table station in the middle of the top roping / lead area. If you are still by the bouldering wall, keep on walking.

We usually meet there for about 10 mins, and then team up in groups of 2 or 3 for top-rope climbing.

If you know that you'll be late, let us know in the comments section, and maybe tell us what you'll be wearing, so we can look out for you. 

BKBS (http://www.bkbsomerville.com/Classes/. If you have a working knowledge of how to belay, you will need to be belay certified before climbing on the ropes. Please flag down a BKBS employee and let them know you need to take a belay test. To pass such a test you will need to display how to tie a double figure eight knot with a fisherman's backup, safely belay a climber up a wall, catch them on a fall, and lower them to the ground safely.

What equipment do I need?  You will need at the bare minimum a harness and climbing shoes. Rentals are available. Grigri devices are provided at every station.

What if I can come, but at a different time?  Just let everyone know you want to climb at a different time and use the community to find a partner for those dates / times.

These are the climbing rates:

ADMISSION (Full day use, you can leave and come back!): 

Day Pass - $25 (Students $20) 
10 Pack - $225 (Students $180)

(Membership Pricing also available)

RENTALS: 

Shoes - $5 
Harness - $5 
Chalk Bag - $2 
Full Gear Kit - $11
results.how_to_find_us: The third table in the middle of the climbing area between 7:00-7:10 PM. It's the table in the middle of the TR \/ Lead area.

results.description:
Cold wind outside, forced hot air inside – winter in New England can dry you out both coming and going. Dry lips, chapped hands, and cracked skin are uncomfortable and persistent. Commercial moisturizers often contain alcohol and can irritate the very skin they’re supposed to heal. Fortunately, it’s simple enough to make your own herbal skin lotion – once you learn how you’ll never go back!

Learn a skin cream recipe to protect and nourish cold-chapped skin. Lotion recipes are based on the chemistry of creating an emulsion, a blend of oil and water soluble ingredients that requires the right ratios and some patience to achieve properly.

This is a hands-on class, no experience required! We’ll discuss how best to select herbs for lotion making, and we’ll perform a demonstration of the emulsifying process along with some tips for troubleshooting runny products.

Wednesday, January 27th, 2016
7:00pm – 9:00pm
25 St. Mary’s Court, Brookline

http://commonwealthherbs.com/winter-skin-care-lotion-making-class/
results.name: Herbal Lotions for Dry Winter Skin

results.description:
PLEASE NOTE: With the ongoing absence of the Cartel's Glass-Chewing Leader due to Family Growth, hosting duties for the regular Wednesday Night Gaming are being handled by a rotating cast of regulars.

Wednesday Night Gaming is our more-or-less weekly free-for-all of strategy gaming goodness downstairs at the Porter Square Panera. There's rarely a set agenda for these events but you are welcome and encouraged to hash out a plan beforehand in comments if you've got something you're dying to play. Nonetheless, you are not required to bring a game to play -- our only requirement is that you bring an open mind!

The event officially begins at 7 PM but people often trickle in early, so you're welcome to sit down to a filler game to get warmed up, or arrange to meet a little early if you've got a group looking to tackle an extra-meaty game.

Please be aware that Panera has been quite gracious about hosting us with minimal fuss -- in order to keep things this way, please respect the hardworking people who work there and, especially, their desire to get out after a long shift.

We'll see you at the gaming table!

results.description:
Now we begin our discussion of 2 Corinthians: "But thanks be to God, who in Christ always leads us in triumphal procession, and through us spreads the fragrance of the knowledge of him everywhere" (2:14).  

Perhaps one of the most troubled churches we see in the New Testament while also being one of the most blessed, Corinth is an example of God's grace not to give up on a struggling church, as well as an example of how to be the church God wants.  1 and 2 Corinthians, Paul's back-to-back letters to the saints in Corinth, provide great insight into unity, maturity, church growth, humility, love, the resurrection, church discipline, salvation, faith, and a number of essential topics for those seeking God.  Come join us in our study of 2 Corinthians!

What if we read the books we love as if they were sacred texts?What would we learn? How might we change?
Join us as we (re)read all seven Harry Potter books and explore what they might teach us about our own lives. Between now and April, each week we’ll read a handful of chapters in our own time and then gather on Wednesday evening to talk through the passages that struck us the most.

Cost: Suggested donation of $10 but all welcome!

To receive updates with reading guidance and the questions we’ll explore each week – sign up here: http://www.harrypottersacredtext.com

This group meets weekly, except for the following dates:
11/25, 12/23, 12/30, 3/16

results.description:
Anyone who loves ASL is welcome to come and be part of the fun! We want to warmly extend an invitation to Deaf people or others fluent/skilled in the language (CODAs for example) to join our group.

This is an easy-going, casual, ASL get-together to meet people who enjoy American Sign Language, who want to brush up on their signing skills, and want to learn more ASL by using it as often as possible.

We strive to have a good time and communicate without using voices. If we need to, we draw or write what we don't know how to sign, and if lots of folks show up, we split up into small groups and mix and mingle, so we can actually see one another clearly, face-to-face and get a good conversation going.
results.how_to_find_us: Right off of exit 6 on 93 south, coming from Boston, TGI Friday's is on your right side at the first set of lights, across from the South Shore Plaza Mall

Wednesday, January 27 Limelight Comedy Club presents its first ever Standup Comedy Rap Battle.

What is the Standup Comedy Rap Battle?

8 comedians compete in a head-to-head bracket-style comedy competition that combines the best elements of standup and rap-battling. It’s like ‘8 mile’ but with better jokes and (probably) worse rapping. Winner of the competition takes home a cash prize and the title of “Standup Rap Battle Champion”

Competing on this show will be:
• Jason Cordova
• Anjan Biswas
• Tim Sturtevant
• Jack Burke
• J Smitty
• Liam McGurk
• Arty P
• Terence Pennington

Doors open at 7 pm, show at 8pm.

Get Tickets: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/limelight-comedy-club-tickets-19758543335?aff=es2

Limelight Comedy Club is Boston's newest stand-up comedy venue, featuring the hottest up and coming comics working today. Located in the heart of Boston's theater district, Limelight Comedy Club is just steps away from the iconic Wilbur Theater, and hosts weekly shows every Wednesday night featuring top talent. $5. 18+.

results.description:
Come and join us for an evening of fun and shared energy. How often do we get an opportunity to be real with each other in Boston?

At TurnON, we play three communication games (just talking, no touching), and you can participate at whatever level feels good to you. Imagine meeting new people in an environment where they feel comfortable to be themselves; a refreshing change from the typical networking or bar conversation. That's what we have created.

TurnON events give you the opportunity to look deeper into yourself, through other people putting quality attention on you, asking questions with genuine curiosity, and then listening - really listening – to your responses. What comes up might surprise you!

It's amazing how connected we can end up feeling - even in a room full of strangers - when we are willing to be authentic. It's like a giant exhale when the rest of the world is asking you to hold it in. In just an hour, you may even forget that you are in Boston.

TurnON Boston is an organization that teaches Orgasmic Meditation, otherwise known as OM. The games we play at TurnON events are designed to create the visceral sensation of Orgasm/OM in your body, without actually doing the practice. At the end of the evening, we will give you a brief description of the practice of OM and information on how to learn more.

$10, payable at the door.

Please arrive on time - we lock the door promptly at 7:40

Limited non-resident parking is available alongside our building on Dudley Street, or plentiful metered spaces on Mass Ave are only one block away (and free after 6pm). We are a 10-minute walk from the Red Line at Davis Square.

Curious about what Orgasmic Meditation is about? More info here:
http://tedxtalks.ted.com/video/TEDxSF-Nicole-Daedone-Orgasm-Th
results.name: TurnON Boston

results.description:
This is the regularly scheduled Wednesday Night MeetUp for the Martial Arts


Together In Motion has opened their gym for our group for Tuesday Nights typically to 9:30 PM


7:30 to 8:00 is centered around those with limited background and the focus is on a basic physical Self Defense system incorporated with progressive boundary setting.

8:00 on the pace picks up with a very open format gathering of Martial Artists of diverse backgrounds who work until everyone gives in to the night.

Donations are always welcome and go towards Not Me! a non profit organization dedicated to providing instruction, conditioning and training to at risk populations

Visit Not-Me.Org if you would like information on the group the donations benefit.

This open mat time is open to all levels and backgrounds of martial arts, typically this is a self directed group which allows everyone to work on practice of their choosing.

Past meetups have had flow drills, throwing practice, locking practice, punching mitt and kicking targets. This really is an open format which allows members to question what they have been taught, share with others and just practice with no pressure of joining a school or formal system.

If you've been out of practice for years or months but want to start doing something again this is the place!

Please join us with a friendly spirit, bring whatever equipment you have or just yourself, uniform or running shorts makes no difference to us. The Together in Motion facility has a large open area with raised spring hard wood floor with dense mats covering, so it is adaptable for just about any type of practice.

Mat shoes or Socks are preferred on the practice surface
results.how_to_find_us: Red Door on the Side of the Building - The Annex
results.name: Open Mat Time

results.description:
Join 50 to 80 or 100 dancers any Wednesday at Dance Freedom!!

We are the original barefoot weekly dance, continuously running for 44 years, that has spawned hundreds if not thousands of other dances around the world.

In a drug, alcohol, and shoe-free environment, we've been making friends and sharing safe and juicy dances for decades. Come join the fun!! Discover the joy of dancing in a totally non-judgmental atmosphere, where anything safe and respectful goes... dance by yourself, in a group, with a same or opposite sex partner, or even just chat and enjoy watching.

First time visitors are welcomed heartily, and get in for half price! Otherwise, you decide what to pay in a range from $10 to $20, or less later in the evening as the event nears its end (information on late admission discounts is at the door). Our friendly dancers range from utterly new at it to very skilled dancers in funk, rock, salsa, modern, jazz, hip-hop, African & Latin and swing, tango, contact improvisation, and our own unique spontaneous creations! Dance with or alongside amazing dancers from local dance troupes as well as with ordinary good-hearted rug cutters. At work they may be doctors, lawyers, programmers, massage therapists, expressive therapists, artists, students, dog walkers, scientists, or anything else, but at heart they all love to dance.

The music runs the gamut: funk, world music, soul & r&b, house, trance, hip-hop, salsa, yoga music, jazz or swing, reggae, disco, you name it! Each DJ from our rotating list has a unique style, but we try to include something for everyone in every set. We keep a good balance in the music: familiar with unusual, timeless with current, melodic with drum-based, and positive lyrics with instrumentals--in all kinds of rhythms & styles! In any given evening, the world music parts of our dance are likely to include at least 3 or so of the following... African, Latin, Indian, Middle Eastern, Caribbean, zydeco, gypsy and much more. You'll hear everything from basic party music to very danceable songs with socially conscious lyrics, but you won't be hearing anything sexist, racist, violent, hating or otherwise divisive.

Start with a soothing stretch and warm up at 7:30, connect with the group and start to boogie at 7:50 with our first DJ of the evening, take a brief break at 8:50 for community announcements and a short unique performance or workshop (or chatting & stretching in a way that doesn't interfere), then cut the rug again by 9:15 at the latest with the evening's second DJ, till 10:30--plenty of time for a great workout and some feel-good inspiration and respiration and perspiration!

At the beginning of each half of the evening's music, everyone who wants to gathers around a centerpiece to hold hands, and dance in a winding chain together to a song with uplifting, connective (or at least beautiful and hypnotic) slow to medium tempo rhythms. (This dance was created from out of a drumming circle on the Cambridge Common in the sixties, after all, and some of that great political and community spirit still lives on here.) Then, it's all dance music, generally building in tempo to a crescendo, slowing down again for some more melodic and slow dance songs for a few minutes, then gradually building to a second crescendo. The second half of the evening's dance follows roughly the same pattern with a different DJ and style, and ends with another circle dance for those who enjoy it.

Dancers are always welcome to help with set-up or take-down, and get in free for doing so! It's a great chance to get to know the community better and be serviceful, as well as to save money and help us to be around for another 42 years... Welcome! For more information, E-mail: [masked]
results.how_to_find_us: Opposite the Cambridge Common, see the Sheraton Hotel w/the big red letters COMMANDER on top.  Enter the stone church just left of hotel, @ entrance closest to hotel.  Follow the hall straight, left and right to the desk to sign in.
results.name: Dance Freedom Robin and Rose  Jessica

results.description:
Ellen Jaffe JonesThe Veg Coach

Creative Cook / Author / Consultant
From our test kitchen to your home kitchen

OK, show of hands.  How many of you eat quinoa as a side dish?
Most cooks use the protein-rich grain as a substitute for rice.
But, I've got a treat for you today.  It's a recipe for Quinoa crisp chocolate balls!
What a way to reward yourself for following a healthy lifestyle.

Find it below.

Consider this too as a tasty approach to getting people interested in coming to one of my FREE cooking classes. This week, Wednesday at 9pm EST, I'll be doing a free class prepping and serving 2 recipes from my book "Eat Vegan on $4 a Day." Bring any questions to our Google Hangout: 

https://plus.google.com/events/c0oegddjuh07utbrq1mv6vm1rfg

Happy cooking,

Ellen Jaffe Jones
The Veg Coach
http://www.vegcoach.com

Buy my books:

Paleo Vegan

Eat Vegan on $4 a Day

Kitchen Divided - Vegan Recipes for Semi-Vegan Households

This is a Quinoa crisp chocolate bar you might find at your local health food store.  
But, my recipe lets you create your own Quinoa chocolate treat.  

It'll satisfy your chocolate cravings and it's so easy to make.  

The recipe is below.

You're Going to Love This!  

Quinoa Crisp Chocolate Treats
by Ellen Jaffe Jones

INGREDIENTS 

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

PREPARATION INSTRUCTIONS

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

Melt chocolate chips in a double-boiler, or place in a microwave-safe bowl and heat for about 60 seconds until the chips develop a slight sheen.  
Place all ingredients in a medium pot (or add to the double-boiler) and over medium heat, and stir constantly for about 5 minutes taking care not to burn the chocolate. 
Form small balls and place on a non-stick cookie sheet.  
Refrigerate for at least 60 minutes before serving.  
For those wanting to reduce fat intake, this can be made without the coconut oil, but make sure the chocolate chips are completely melted.

This is an Online Webinar. You Must Register To Participate. 

CLICK ON THIS LINK TO REGISTER  (More instructions can be found at the bottom of this message)

WHEN: January 28, 2016 (4:00 pm - 5:00 pm EUROPE/LONDON)

ORGANIZER & Host: SmartFocus - Jessica Stephens Twitter @SmartFocusWorld

CO-HOST: Forrester Research, inc.- Julie Ask

----------------------------------------------------------

If you make one marketing New Year’s resolution for 2016, it should be to create, enhance or refine your mobile moments strategy. 

With consumers engaging with their mobile devices[masked] each day, that adds up to over 30 billion mobile moments each day in the US alone. Grabbing your customer’s attention in that mobile moment to drive engagement or conversions will be the biggest challenge for marketers in 2016. Those that deliver contextually relevant engagements, personalized for each customer around their location, activity and device, will be the ones who triumph. Marketers need to believe in the new opportunities that can emerge from not only implementing a mobile strategy, but also understanding that mobile moments support and engage customers, throughout their whole customer journey. In an exciting new webinar ‘Mobile New Year’s Resolutions’ experts from SmartFocus and a guest speaker from Forrester Research, Inc. will discuss the challenges and opportunities that face marketers for the future of mobile marketing by covering:

Why attend this webinar:

1. Learn how mobile commerce is now bigger than ever

2. The top 5 mobile resolutions you need to follow in 2016

3. The importance of an automation system to maintain continuous, relevant and contextual engagements

More information about the speakers:

SmartFocus - Jessica Stephens - CMO - Twitter @SmartFocusWorld

Jess brings an invaluable breadth of marketing and leadership experience to SmartFocus. With an unashamedly enthusiastic approach to data, she knows all about the huge impact disruptive technology has in bringing brands closer to their consumers. As the Chief Marketing Officer, Jess is responsible for bringing SmartFocus’ brand to life and telling our unique story globally. Prior to joining SmartFocus, Jess was the Founder and Director at TagPoints and held senior leadership roles at MoneySupermarket Local Deals, Local Daily Deals and Filofax.

Forrester Research, inc. - Julie Ask - VP Principal Analyst - Twitter @JulieAsk

Julie serves eBusiness & Channel Strategy Professionals. Her 25 years of work experience is balanced between the engineering and management consulting work she did in the first half of her career and her work as an analyst for the past 12 years. The combination of technical and business expertise positions prepared her well to work with business leaders to identify new opportunities offered by mobile technology and to develop strategies to engage with consumers on mobile devices. She has worked with hundreds of clients across retail, travel, banking, insurance, CPG, healthcare, and more to advise and guide the development of their mobile strategies. Julie's research and analysis have been widely cited in publications including The Wall Street Journal, The New York Times, USA Today, BusinessWeek, RCR Wireless, and The Onion, as well as on CBS, NBC, and PBS.

Mobile ready Recording available,  Slides/PDF available

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Thursday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
Save the time and date: Thursday January 28, 2016  12:30pm, somewhere in Arlington..


Remember when you worked in an office,and they gave you some time to eat lunch in the cafeteria, and  you actually pulled yourself away from your desk and went and ate lunch with other people?  

Nah, I don't remember that either, but it sure sounds like fun.  And, it's the law.  If your employer denied you a lunch break, you'd be filing a complaint with the state so fast.  

About 25 people expressed interest, which means that probably five to eight people will show up.  The others will all have good excuses, such as, "It's too cold," "I'm too tired," "I have too much work," "I have a deadline," "my clients need me," etc.  I don't want to hear your excuses, Please don't bore me with those lame-o excuses, I just want you to show up.

RSVP by obtaining a free ticket at eventrbire, first come, first served: 

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/monday-125-collegial-lunch-for-people-who-work-at-home-in-arlingtonbelmontcambridge-tickets-20091265516


 that way I'll know you're coming, and be able to contact you easily.  That will also help  to limit the attendance. If you think this idea can fly, please do sign up and show up, and then we can repeat this pleasure again next week. bests,

-rsr-

Ron Rothenberg

4Buyers RE

[masked]
