results.description:
Chef and owner Pankaj Pradhan, owner and operator of Red Lentil Vegan & Vegetarian Restaurant in Watertown, has opened Wild Rice Vegan Cafe, a breakfast and lunch multi-fusion restaurant.

The grand opening of Wild Rice Vegan Cafe will be held on Friday, January 29, and Saturday, January 30, from 6 AM to 3 PM each day. 

The event will feature an all-you-can-eat buffet of exclusive Wild Rice vegan breakfast and lunch dishes, from 11 AM - 2 PM. 

Guests will also be able to pick up coupons and enter to win gift cards from Wild Rice, Red Lentil, and other area businesses. 

For complete details, please check out the official press release: http://bit.ly/wrlaunch­


Phone:[masked]
Address: 71 Elm Street at Monroe Avenue, Watertown, MA 02472 (address for the now-closed Grappa)

WiFi equipped.

It's on the #70 MBTA bus route.

Read about the Wild Rice Vegan Cafe (and see photos):
http://boston.eater.com/2015/12/14/10104088/wild-rice-vegan-cafe-watertown-open


http://boston.eater.com/2015/7/21/9008809/red-lentil-renovations-new-vegan-venture-2015


http://boston.eater.com/2015/12/14/10104088/wild-rice-vegan-cafe-watertown-open


Wild Rice Vegan Cafe - 71 Elm Street, Watertown, MA
Locally sourced vegan world cuisine in a casual café environment. Wild Rice offers vegan breakfast and lunch, cold-pressed fresh juices, smoothies, and coffee at the counter. Many dishes are gluten-free and soy-free.

Patrons enjoy quick carry-out service or dine-in in a relaxed, well-lit seating area.

Free Wi-fi is available. 
Wild Rice is regularly open seven days per week:
for breakfast from 6–11 AM
and for lunch from 11 AM–3 PM.
They offer off-site catering and rent their space for groups of up to 45.

Red Lentil Vegan & Vegetarian Restaurant - 600 Mount Auburn Street, Watertown, MAOpened in 2009. Red Lentil hosts charity and vegan-related community events like the Boston Vegetarian Society Annual Harvest Dinner and showcases food at local area events like the Boston Local Food Festival, Boston Greenfest, and the Taste of WGBH Food & Wine Festival. It’s a more traditional, sit-down space for lunch, dinner, and brunch.

The menu offers both vegan and vegetarian world cuisine. Also offerings catering and space rental. Winner: 2013 TripAdvisor Certificate of Excellence, 2013 Nature’s Plate Award (Nature Conservancy).
Well-reviewed:  http://theredlentil.com/press

Chef Pankaj Pradhan
Chef grew up vegetarian in Kolkata and, after working as a chef for both Hyatt Hotels and Carnival Cruise Lines, he completed his culinary training in France. He has visited over 40 countries.

He moved to NYC to work at an Indian restaurant, but he learned that it wasn’t ideal for his world-cuisine background.

He relocated to Rhode Island where he worked at a vegetarian restaurant and, mid-2009, moved to Boston and opened Red Lentil.

In 2014, Pradhan began a partnership with Harvard University Dining Services. He trained dining staff and introduced vegan cuisine as a dining option for university students.

And in 2015, he opened his second Watertown restaurant: Wild Rice Vegan Cafe.
results.name: Grand Opening: Wild Rice Vegan Cafe

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball.

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Friday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
Do you want OTHER people to eat fresh produce?  Then help us - each Wednesday late afternoon - bag vegetables (and some fruit) for the neighbors in McCormack Senior Center.  Usually there are also freshly-baked loaves of bread, also (baked that morning - Jessica's Bakery in North Andover - often from other sites, also).

It's an assembly line, then take home a bag (or two) of produce for yourself. 

Bring your business cards, smartphone, or notepad, and prepare to exchange contact info with other volunteers you like.  Volunteers come from several sources (not merely from this meetup or others: Craigslist, EventBrite, local schools - colleges, graduate and professional schools, academies, training programs, etc.) 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
VOLUNTEERING for $2/bag of produce in South Boston

McCormack Task Force
345 Old Colony Ave.
Next to St. Monica's Church
(Near Andrew Red Line)
Inside Task Force building 
Fridays 2:30 - 3:30 PM (Show up by 2 pm for setup)

Each Friday, from 2:00 - 4:00 pm

We will be VOLUNTEERING for the weekly Friday midafternoon $2/bag of produce at McCormack Senior Center in mSouth jBoston.

When you volunteer, 
YOU will ALSO TAKE HOME one or two of those "$2 bags"! 
We've had 55 volunteers, and we've had 7.  Workloads vary!

Volunteers unload the truck, set up 3 banquet tables, set up the food in order of desntiy (potatoes on bottom - tomatoes and bananas and berries and kale on top), then fill each bag (and 'stack' them upright by one another - for the 'paying neighbors' to pick up (for $2).

We arrive around 2 pm (maybe as late as 2:30 pm) and work until 4 pm (can leave as early as 3:30 pm if we've finished).

http://www.buzzfile.com/Home/Map?m=7790814

Near Columbia Road, Andrew Red Line stop - about 7 minutes walk, 0.3 miles

Wear comfortable clothing that allows you to move flexibly and to actually work, lifting heavy bags of food. 

Bring friends!  Forward the invitation to others!

Please e-mail organizer with your e-mail address and cellphone (in case we need to converse about this more, or contact you before the event).

Invite FRIENDS through the Facebook, LinkedIn, and Twitter 'share'

Question:
This sounds like a great deal, but is it meant for those in need, as is the case with food banks?

Answer:
No qualifications - no limits
We have way more than AMPLE food for any intended audiences, and the operation is bettered if MORE people take the food than if FEWER take the food.

Therefore, there is NO QUALIFICATION (no test of need) and no limit to how much you can cart off (just pay $2/bag and $1/loaf of bread).  That's why I post it on a meetup like this.
Make us busy - very busy.

results.description:
Lets check out this very Finnish-Wood exhibit at the BAC's first floor gallery on 320 Newbury Street along with the Boston Scandinavian Group.

Pine, spruce, larch. These tree species cover the majority of Finland. This abundance of wood formed a material and spatial culture that connects to the sky perceived through upright trees. Against this bounty, Finnish architecture expressively incorporates itself as a zone between often-frozen ground and sky.

More info: http://the-bac.edu/experience-the-bac/news-and-events/events/annual-rings-exhibition

Finland prides itself on its long-established woodworking traditions and widespread appreciation for quality craftsmanship and design. After a walk around the the free exhibition, we will chat over drinks at Tapeo at 266 Newbury for a very civil, very Scandinavian discussion about the exhibit and/or other topics.
results.name: The Boston Architectural College: Exhibition on Wood Architecture In Finland

venue.name: Microsoft  NERD New England Research & Development Center

results.description:
Cannabis prohibition has led to a lack of scientific research around its medical use.  With research and science finally being applied to medical marijuana we can now begin distinguishing anecdotal evidence from empirical data.  We can also begin to realize the extent of research that needs to be done.  

Data / Lore will present our audience with hard science, anecdotal evidence and the research left to accomplish around medical use of marijuana.

Speakers

--------------------

Dr. Lester Grinspoon, Associate Professor Emeritus of Psychiatry at Harvard Medical School and Published Author

--------------------

As marijuana use became more and more prevalent during the 1960's Dr. Lester Grinspoon became interested in researching the scientific nature of the cannabis plant. He was astounded when he discovered that marijuana was much less harmful than once believed. He published his findings in his 1971 Harvard University Press best seller, "Marihuana Reconsidered." Carl Sagan, renowned astrophysicist and cosmologist was close friends Dr. Grinspoon, and wrote an essay preface to "Marihuana Reconsidered" under the pseudonym Mr. X.

Dr. Grinspoon was also Senior Psychiatrist at the Massachusetts Mental Health Center in Boston for four decades. He is an ardent supporter of legalizing herbal marijuana for both medical and adult recreational use. Grinspoon often describes how marijuana helped his young son Danny overcome horrible nausea and vomitting associated with his leukemia chemotherapy treatments in the 1970's. Dr. Grinspoon is a graduate of Tufts University and Harvard Medical School. He lives in Newton and well published in the field of drugs and policy.

Learn more: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lester_Grinspoon

--------------------

Norton Arbelaez Esq., Founder of the Colorado Medical Marijuana Industry Group, Principal at RiverRock Medical Marijuana Center, and Spokesman and Consultant for New England Treatment Access.

--------------------

Norton graduated from Tulane University Law School in 2006 and by 2009 found himself relocating to Denver where he founded RiverRock Medical Marijuana Center after a family member’s palliative use of cannabis convinced him of its medicinal value. In 2010, Norton founded Colorado’s Medical Marijuana Industry Group which is a non-profit lobbying and policy group promoting responsible cannabis regulatory frameworks and educating policy makers on cannabis related concerns.

Recently Norton has been spending more and more time in Massachusetts as NETA rolls out and becomes a reality serving patients at its two locations in Northampton and Brookline. His work for NETA is helping them implement best practices and is also creating new jobs in Massachusetts. 

Learn More: http://www.medicaljane.com/directory/professional/norton-arbelaez/

--------------------

Scott Churchill., Director of Methodology and Compliance at Massachusetts Cannabis Research Labs (MCR Labs)

--------------------

Scott teaches Cannabis Science and Safety at The Northeastern Institute of Cannabis in Natick and is the Director of Methodology and Compliance at MCR Labs, LLC. 

As a cannabis professional Scott teaches science and safety to the future workers of the cannabis industry of New England in addition he helps provide ISO 17025 accredited laboratory testing for the cannabis community as well as research and development services.


Connect with Scott: https://www.linkedin.com/in/scottchurchill1

--------------------

Lindsay Miller., Activist, Advocate, & Co-Founder of GLASS (Greater Lowell Area Science-based Skeptics)

--------------------

Lindsay has been disabled with chronic pain and illness for almost half her life. Among her medical conditions are pudendal neuralgia, interstitial cystitis, migraines, endometriosis, and lower spinal pain…to name a few. Despite these hindrances, you may have recently heard of Lindsay’s activism from viral news reports on her being the first pastafarian atheist allowed to wear a colander in a Massachusetts drivers' license photo. 

Lindsay holds a biology degree from UMass Boston and has a real passion for science. As she makes bits of progress in improving her quality of life, it is very important to her that the treatments she chooses are based in scientific evidence. Lindsay will be joining us to share her unique view on why and how she uses cannabis to help control her pain. 


Connect with Lindsay: https://www.facebook.com/Daldrianna


About Microsoft New England our Venue Sponsor

Microsoft New England promotes research, software innovation & community in the heart of the northeast.  Bostonians are pretty clever folks. From Ben Franklin to the Big Dig–they’ve been solving difficult problems in creative ways for centuries. And today the Greater Boston area is home to cutting edge tech companies, world class hospitals, a vibrant startup community, plus a few universities you might have heard of. So when Microsoft needed the brightest minds to work on tomorrow’s technologies, Boston was the natural choice. And we love our New England home. The people. The ideas. The history. The culture. The food. It’s what makes us Microsoft New England.

https://microsoftnewengland.com/ 

Want to know about parking around Microsoft? Check out Boston's parking guide on Parkopedia for information. http://en.parkopedia.com/parking/boston/


Legal Disclaimer  

Views or opinions expressed by speakers or sponsors at our local Cannabis Society community events do not necessarily express the opinion or views of the Cannabis Society organization and we do not take responsibility for the views expressed or the actions of speakers or sponsors at our local events. The Cannabis Society does not distribute cannabis.

The Cannabis Society is Growing  

Our group has grown by leaps and bounds these past few years and we are proud to announce that the Cannabis Society is going to continue to grow and develop our ecosystem with groundbreaking events centering around medical cannabis, technology, art, and science. We couldn’t do it without our members and we want to thank you for being apart of this growing organization.

2016 Martin Luther King Jr.Celebration Keynote and Performance

This celebration features a performance by Ledisi and a keynote address by Beverly Morgan-Welch, the associate director of external affairs at the Smithsonian's National Museum of African American History and Culture, opening on the National Mall in 2016.

This event is copresented by the

Museum of African American History, Boston and Nantucket

and

Berklee College of Music

FIRST COME FIRST SEATED FOR FREE

BAG POLICY:

All bags are subject to search. Refusal of a bag search will result in denial of entry to the event.

DIRECTIONS AND PARKING:

By "T": Take the Green Line to the Hynes Convention Center stop. Exit left onto Massachusetts Avenue and cross Boylston Street. The Berklee Performance Center is about 30 yards from the corner. Consult the MBTA Web site for bus routes and schedules.

From points west: Take the Massachusetts Turnpike (Interstate 90) east to exit 22 (Prudential Center exit), which begins in a tunnel. When you reach this exit, bear left onto street level and stay left onto Huntington Avenue. Merge into the right lane and turn right at the third traffic light onto Massachusetts Avenue. The Berklee Performance Center is on your right, just past the third light.

From points due south: Take Route 93 north (Southeast Expressway) to the Massachusetts Avenue/Roxbury exit (a right-lane exit). Turn right onto Massachusetts Avenue at the traffic light. Continue on Massachusetts Avenue. The Berklee Performance Center is on your right, at the intersection of Mass Ave. and Boylston Street.

From points due north: Take Route 93 south or Route 1 south. These roads converge at Boston's central artery. Follow the signs for Storrow Drive heading west and stay in the center lane. Take the Fenway exit and get into the left lane. Make a hard left onto Boylston Street and continue to the Massachusetts Avenue intersection. Turn right. The Berklee Performance Center is on the left, about 30 yards from the corner.

Parking

Limited metered parking is available on the streets surrounding the Berklee Performance Center and Berklee College of Music.

Parking is also available at nearby parking garages:

The Hynes Auditorium Garage, located on 50 Dalton Street next to Bukowski's Tavern. Maximum rate for evening parking (4 p.m.-5 a.m.) is $15.00. The Berklee Performance Center offers a $5 discount with validation. Weekdays before 4 p.m. patrons will receive a discount of $2.50 OFF the first 1/2 hour and $2.50 off the second 1/2 hour (or $5 off the first hour). To receive discounts and promotional rates patrons must present concert ticket and parking ticket for validation at the Berklee Performance Center box office during business hours on event day. Tickets must be validated to receive any eligible discounts. Visit pilgrimparking.com for more information.The Prudential Center Garage on Boylston Street, just past the Hynes Convention Center. The garage may offer a discount if you present your Berklee ticket stub to the garage attendant. For more information or directions, call the garage office at[masked] or visit their website at prudentialcenter.com.The First Church of Christian Science Garage, located below the reflection pool, offers evening rates of $12 for up to two hours before and after each event. Evening rates during Symphony Hall events and weekends are $20. Click here for more information.The Haviland Street Garage, directly across from the BPC (behind Starbucks) on 5 Haviland Street and 1085 Boylston Street. <a>patparking.com</a>The Back Bay Hilton, located on Dalton Street. Heading north on Massachusetts Avenue, take a right onto Boylston Street and then another right at the first light, just before the Hynes Convention Center.Danker & Donohue Garage, located at 341 Newbury Street. Call[masked] for current rates and information.Central Parking Jazz, located at 1087 Boylston Street. Call[masked] for current rates and information.Sheraton Boston Hotel Parking Garage, located at 39 Dalton Street

The aforementioned businesses are listed as a courtesy to our patrons. The Berklee Performance Center and Berklee College of Music are not affiliated with these garages and cannot be held responsible for any lost, stolen or damaged items.

Accessible Parking Locations

Accessible parking spaces are available at all of the garages/lots listed. Accessible street parking spaces do exist in the Back Bay but are extremely limited. At present, eight spaces exist near the theater and are designated by street signs that mark the area reserved for accessible parking. A Disabled Placard may be used in any parking space designated as HP parking. Other parking ordinances may be in effect. All designated parking rules should be obeyed. Massachusetts law allows vehicles with proper Disabled Parking authority to disregard most - but not all - public meter fees. Note, however, Massachusetts Port Authority does not exempt meter fees for Disabled Parking. Do not park in a cross-hatch area (Zebra Stripe) adjacent to an HP space. This area is reserved for van ramp access.

Two spaces exist on Belvedere Street, near Massachusetts Avenue.One space exists on Haviland Street, near the intersection of Hemenway Street.Two more exist in front of 15 Hemenway Street.One space exists where St. Cecilia Street intersects with Boylston Street.Two spaces exist where Massachusetts Avenue intersects with Boylston Street, next to the old bank building.

All of these space are conveniently located within a short distance from the Berklee Performance Center. Please obey all posted signs. Due to street cleaning, public events, snow emergencies or construction, availability and accessibility status of any given space is subject to change without notice.

In general, I arrive at the theater an hour before the show to start gathering people, and we head in for seats about 30 minutes before the show, so we can sit together. This also allows us to take turns getting snacks, etc., before the previews start.  It also allows for any unexpected, last minute changes at the theater.  Although fairly infrequent, having wiggle room to exchange tickets, etc. is VERY helpful.

Please note, everyone is responsible for buying their own tickets.  And while it is possible to buy your ticket at the door, shows often sell out. I strongly advise you to buy your tickets in advance.  I will announce when tickets go on sale on Fandango. Please do NOT buy tickets until I have finalized the time.

Movie Details:

Release date: January 29, 2016
(3D/2D theaters and IMAX 3D)

Studio: Walt Disney Pictures

Director: Craig Gillespie

Screenwriters: Eric Johnson, Scott Silver, Paul Tamasy

Starring: Chris Pine, Casey Affleck, Ben Foster, Holliday Grainger, John Ortiz, Eric Bana

Genre: Thriller, Action

Official website:

Facebook


Plot Summary:

A heroic action-thriller, “The Finest Hours” is the remarkable true story of the greatest small boat rescue in Coast Guard history.Presented in Digital 3D™ and IMAX® 3D, the film will transport audiences to the heart of the action, creating a fully-immersive cinematic experience on an epic scale. On February 18, 1952, a massive nor’easter struck New England, pummeling towns along the Eastern seaboard and wreaking havoc on the ships caught in its deadly path, including the SS Pendleton, a T-2 oil tanker bound for Boston, which was literally ripped in half, trapping more than 30 sailors inside its rapidly-sinking stern. As the senior officer on board, first assistant engineer Ray Sybert (Casey Affleck) soon realizes it is up to him to take charge of the frightened crew and inspire the men to set aside their differences and work together to ride out one of the worst storms to ever hit the East Coast. Meanwhile, as word of the disaster reaches the U.S. Coast Guard station in Chatham, Massachusetts, Warrant Officer Daniel Cluff (Eric Bana) orders a daring operation to rescue the stranded men. Despite overwhelming odds, four men, led by Coast Guard Captain Bernie Webber (Chris Pine), set out in a wooden lifeboat with an ill-equipped engine and little, if any, means of navigation, facing frigid temperatures, 60-foot high waves and hurricane-force winds.

venue.name: Harvard Film Archive

results.description:
Introduction by Sarah Keller - Live Musical Accompaniment by Robert Humphreville

Friday January 29 at 7pm

The Cinémathèque Française today holds more than 40,000 film prints, but Jean Epstein’s The Fall of the House of Usher of 1928 was the first. Given a little money to initiate his long-dreamt-of film museum, Henri Langlois procured Epstein’s silent masterwork straightaway—“not only the ultimate expression of ten years of experimentation,” Langlois observed, “but their justification.” For Epstein, however, it was only one in a long line of turning points. After channeling Poe, he repaired to Brittany’s remote islands to make a series of films that now seem positively prophetic in their fusion of ethnographic principles and avant-garde aesthetics. “It was and still is very important to set the camera free in the extreme,” Epstein wrote in 1930, and, indeed, he approached each new work as if the medium itself hung in the balance.


 ½ x 11 (Six et demi, onze)

Directed by Jean Epstein. With Edmond Van Daële, Nino Constantini, René Ferté
France 1927, 35mm, b/w, silent, 83 min. French intertitles with English subtitles

A fascinating transitional work in Epstein’s career, 6 ½ x 11 situates the camera’s divining powers in an otherwise conventional melodrama. The title refers to the standard format of a Kodak camera, and indeed cameras play a pivotal role in the narrative’s many reversals. Two brothers fall in love with the same woman, consecutive cases ofamour fou anticipating the nouvelle vague’s penchant for reflexive love triangles by some thirty years. “There was a time not long ago when hardly a single American drama was without a scene in which a revolver was slowly pulled out of a half-open drawer,” Epstein reflected in 1926. “I loved that revolver. It seemed the symbol of a thousand possibilities”—and the genesis of 6 ½ x 11.

His Head (Sa tête) Directed by Jean Epstein. With France Dhelia, Nino Constantini, Irma Perrot
France 1929, 35mm, b/w, silent, 32 min. French intertitles with English subtitles

Made during Epstein’s productive period at the end of the 1920s, this short packs a tale of mistaken identity, about a Hitchcockian “wrong man” accused of murder, into half an hour. “The swift, deft filming and editing,” as scholar and historian Sarah Keller puts it, shows the filmmaker “at the height of his powers even when treating a slight subject.”

Sarah Keller is Assistant Professor of Art and Cinema Studies at the University of Massachusetts-Boston and co-editor of Jean Epstein: Critical Essays and New Translations (University of Chicago Press 2012).

See you at the movie,

John

results.description:
Each and every Friday, we're proud to open the doors of our music school in Central Square for a FREE seminar, demo or meet-up. Hell, we’ll even throw a classical music concert or two. What's in store this week? Let's find out:

Using Max for Live BeatSeeker with a modular synthesizer:

The new Max for Live device, BeatSeeker, has opened up a new avenue for live performers to sync their Live sessions with the "push and pull" of a live drummer. However, BeatSeeker is capable of much more than just syncing your sessions tempo to a drummers groove, it can read any rhythmic audio input and adjust your Live sessions tempo accordingly. During the workshop we will explore BeatSeeker and its functionality, as well as some basic synthesis in the context of a modular synthesizer environment. Then we will explore the possibilities of syncing a Live session with an ever evolving modular synthesizer patch.

More info to come! For now get tickets and RSVP here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/ableton-live-meet-up-129-free-tickets-20930310121

results.description:
• THE BOSTON DRUM CIRCLE

• A high-energy, FUN, celebration of drumming and community. For beginners who want to try something new, their friends, experienced drummers, dancers beginners to experts. NO EXPERIENCE REQUIRED!

• We celebrate the traditions - rhythms that have built energy for hundreds of years for celebration, dance, ritual - just plain FUN! As well as whatever you bring to it!

• We gather together every other Friday evening. Check the schedule, grab your drum (or use ours) and have a blast!

We'll have drums to share, and support for newcomers, and energy for everyone.

Recent accolades!

“Great fun! Good rhythms. Very accommodating leader and group for this beginner. Will be back!”

Adrienne S 10/14

It was an amazing experience .. It was nice to feel free from the world and it's problems .. It's was so relaxing, can't wait to drum again ..thanks!

Justin 6/14

Was an awesome experience, I love hand drumming but really the main reason I came was to relieve stress due to family health situations and the circle definitely met my needs. Alan did a great job leading the circle with the drumming and the short history lessons about drumming and Africa. I will be coming back.

Paul 10/13

This Drum Circle is a great stress reliever after a long week of work and I wish it were every Friday night!! Boston Drum Cirlce attracts a wonderful , eclectic group of people that share the common bond of hand drumming. It is always wonderful to have the multi talented Fanta leading the Circle. Her singing, dancing, and drumming are all 5 star. Thank you for a great night of Drumming!

Carla 8/13

We can't wait to meet you! See you soon....

Alan and Fanta

results.description:
January 29th- February 6th 2016

Go here to sign up: http://www.photoflytravel.org/costa-rica-adventure-safari-tour/

We've perfected our Costa Rica Adventure with PhotoFly Travel Club and are ready for more next January! Check out the highlights below and email us for the full daily itinerary at [masked].

8 nights/ 9 day adventure tour through Costa Rica!

Breakfast everyday

7 lunches, 7 dinners (All meals throughout)

Private guide & driver (Local professionals with years of experience and qualifications)

Awesome, unique hotels and lodges throughout

Explore the famous and historic section of San Jose right next to our hotel!

Guided tour of coffee plantation

Discover the Poas Volcano (Still an active volcano and its colorful crater is one of the widest and deepest in the world)

Amazing Bat Tour! (Trained guide will let those interested a safe opportunity to touch, feed and release safely captured bats!)

Vida Campesina Farm (Organic farm lets us see real life in the Costa Rican countryside with a farming family)

Arenal Volcano National Park guided Lava flow hike (lava rocks and occasional eruptions, this volcano is surrounded by lush rainforest and second growth that cover the old lava flows and river sides)

Optional Zip Line Adventure (One of the longest and best in the world!)

Optional Early Morning Bird Watching everyday (included and offered for the photo and bird enthusiasts!)

Adventure to Fortuna Waterfall (Beautiful 200 foot-tall waterfall receives its cool clear waters from the pristine forested mountains of Arenal National Park)

Wetlands Boat Tour (Floating safari: variety of resident and migratory birds plus three different species of monkeys, iguanas, sloths, turtles and caymans)

Malekus Indian Reserve (Unique history and cultural experience: medicinal plant garden, enjoy a reenactment of a traditional Maleku dance, and try out their version of archery!)

Heliconia butterfly and hummingbird gardens (Blue Morphos, Zebra Butterflies, Small Postman, Glasswings, Monarchs & RARE hummingbirds like Green Thorntail, Coppery-headed Emerald and White-bellied Mountain-gem) Nearby we’ll search for toucans, motmots, trogons, poison dart frogs, howling monkeys, and white-faced capuchin monkeys!

Blue River Hike and Thermal Springs (See the famous Pénjamo River which is also known as the Blue River. The river is tinted a turquoise color by volcanic minerals. We’ll , enjoy the many natural pools, swim and relax)

Relax at one of best beaches in Costa Rica: Playa Panama (We’ll finish the adventure at this pristine, world renowned beach! The taupe sand beach is bathed by clear waters with a soft current. Many water sports can be enjoyed including fishing, swimming, and windsurfing, among others, from a beach surrounded by the exuberant vegetation after which the beach was named.)

All Taxes, Fees, Transfers included (excludes airport departure tax)

Airfare is not included but we will help you find a good flight!

Roommate Pairing to save money as always!

Email us to see daily itinerary at [masked].

Join Us!

*For our solo travelers I will pair you up with someone of the same sex unless single occupancy is requested.

Price: $[masked]

*Single Supplement:[masked]

OR

Deposit:[masked]

Go here to sign up: http://www.photoflytravel.org/costa-rica-adventure-safari-tour/

results.description:
Back by popular demand, Brian and I return to the Temple to do this beautiful sound bath! Our focus will be radiating your being with love and light!

So if you come to the Buddhist Temple for a sound healing, what can you expect? When you come in, you take your shoes off, then you walk to the Dharma Hall which will be on your immediate right at the top of the stairs. We'll start with a short introduction and discuss each of our intentions for how we want to work with the sound and then meditate for a few minutes to tune into each of our specific intentions. The general theme will be new years resolutions - specifically bringing in the vibrations we need! Then, everyone will sit or lie down on super comfy pillow mats (bring your own blanket) and we'll begin our journey into sound.

I start by playing the 500 pound cast-iron temple bell and then I move into the sweet sounds of my Tibetan singing bowls. What follows, I can't exactly say, as the sound decides what it wants to say. But you can expect to hear the rainbow voice, the sound of the overtone chant singing with the tibetan bowls. You won't be able to tell which is which but this is all part of the dance. You will even feel what it's like to have the bowls played on you as the sound moves your energy where it needs to go. Tingshas, tuning forks, rattles and more are all part of the play as the sound moves you to rest at your destination without ever having moved. So, please, come and feel something unique. You never leave anywhere exactly the same, but when it comes to sound healing, you will leave sounding more like yourself :)

Please bring a blanket, a pillow and a yoga mat to enhance the comfort of your experience! Offerings are freely accepted, suggested donation of 20$. Love, light and vibration

Sarah
results.name: Sound Bath in the Buddhist Temple (Men and Women)

group.name: Sound Bath - Sound Healing Circles - Women's Circles

results.description:
Boston Area Philosophy Discussions, the earlier incarnation of the Social Philosophizers Club, discussed the topic of Atheism, Theism and the Rest of Us twice before. In both cases—December 10, 2010 and January 27, 2012—the meetings proved to be memorable and highly successful. It's been four years, and I think there are lots of reasons to revisit the topic again.

***************************************

ADMISSION FEE: Gold Members are admitted free.  All other members are required to pay a $5.50 admission fee, which is due on or before Thursday, January 21st.  PLEASE PAY HERE.  Any unpaid registration (RSVP) as of Friday, January 22nd will be changed to "not attending." Afterwards, you may re-register your RSVP to “Yes, attending” but you must first process your payment.

****************************************

I’m in "the rest of us" category. The big question concerning questions about‘God’ is not whether s/he/it exists but about what the word means. If we do not agree on what ‘God’ means then how are we going to form an opinion about whether or not God exists. And, if the question is not so much a question about existence than it is about meaning then the distinctions between atheism, theism and deism become very muddled. Atheism, therefore, seems to me to be just as muddled as the various forms of belief in God. What is it that the atheist does not believe in? The atheist has just as much need for clarity on the meaning of ‘God’as do religionists if only because you cannot disbelieve in something that you cannot define, because if you cannot define your term you cannot put it into a statement which you think you want to refute. Hence, the statement, “God does not exist” is meaningless unless you are prepared to define the thing that you want to reject.

Buddhism provides an interesting focal point. I remember, a number of years ago, listening to a radio interview with Michio Kaku, the well-known physicist and writer of popular books on the subject. I don’t recall the exact context, but a question about God or spirituality came up and he said that he was raised in a Buddhist home and that Buddhists are 'atheists’. That comment struck me because I really do not think of Buddhism as being an atheist religion which,anyway, is probably an oxymoron. I have since come to understand that Buddhism is considered non-theistic (Kaku's comment aside) because while it rejects deities it is distinguishable from atheism. I am not a student of the atheist movement, but my impression is that most people who today call themselves 'atheist' refer to a very scientific, naturalistic and radical empiricist view of reality that rejects any sense of immateriality and not merely theism, while also embracing a humanism that deeply supports the notion that we don’t need to believe in God to be moral or good.


In conclusion, my view is that the God issue is a big muddle that, while having speculative value, has little else. For my part, I do not consider myself to be an atheist, however, I do not think one needs to believe in God to be good. My personal speculations flow more in a non-atheistic Buddhistic direction (but I do not consider myself to be a Buddhist either) of believing that there is a transcendent Mind (of some sort) that is complementary with notions of spirituality. This perspective can be very unscientific! But I believe in science. I hope that I have at least provided some food for thought...


********************************

Gold and Bronze Memberships entitle you to attend a wide range of great events. Consider purchasing a paid membership today! CLICK HERE

********************************

Menu

FOOD AND BEVERAGES: This restaurant is extremely accommodating and allows us to stay until closing (11:00pm) if we choose.  It is not fair if they are not fairly compensated.  And we use a large percentage of the total seats in the house! The basic cost, in addition to any relevant admission fee, is $20 (this covers your entree, 3 or 4 shared appetizers per table, tax and gratuity but not drinks) but, if your prefer,  you can also calculate your purchase exactly rather than rounding it off to $20. DRINKS--BOTH ALCOHOL AND NON-ALCOHOL-- ARE ORDERED AND PAID FOR SEPARATELY BY EACH ATTENDEE. If on a rare occasion you only order a drink or an appetizer, or if you do not order anything, then you will owe a minimum charge of $12 to compensate the restaurant for their service.  If there should be a shortfall, which is unlikely, then the group agrees to chip in to cover the difference. By attending this event you hereby agree to this policy.

Sometimes some of us head out for a late night prolongation of the evening at a nearby pub. However, during these occasions please do not carpool to the pub: drive your car down the street and re-park it at the pub because there is TOWING after the little mall area closes for the night.

To reach me at my office, call[masked]

The fabulous, fun-filled event begins with a  African Nia class from 7:45 to 9:15 and continues with dj'd dancing until  11:30pm music provided by the extraordinary Nina Coil

Dancers of all ages and abilities are invited to dance barefoot, any way you like, with or without a partner, in a smoke and alcohol free environment. Children are welcome.

Dance Friday 7:45-9:00 African Nia with Alice Heller; 9:15-11:30 Dance to Dj’d music by NinaJan 29 @ 7:45 PM – 11:30 PMAfrican Nia with Alice Heller

</a>Come celebrate being in your body with a delicious blend of earthy African dance moves and heavenly Nia Technique. This all level workshop includes dance, martial arts and healing arts like yoga set to great music that will inspire your somatic experience.

Alice Heller blends her love of rhythm, movement and spirit to bring you a multidimensionally accessible movement class. No experience required as her classes are based on the body’s way. She is a Certified Blue Belt Nia instructor and an African dance teacher. <a href="http://www.alicehellerdance.com/">www.alicehellerdance.com


After class enjoy dancing to dj’d music by Nina.

Dance Friday is an activity of the non-profit Movement Collective. Suggested Donation: $15 8pm-9:15, $10-15 after 9:30, $5-10 after 11,  under  23 years old $5-15, or donate 45 minutes of your time to help out.  We recommend casual, light-weight, comfortable clothing that you can  move in.

BIDA welcomes you back for another Spark in the Dark alternative contra, on friday January 29th, from 8-11 pm.

Our caller for the evening will be ever-lovely Mary Wesley, with music by the excellent Buddy System, aka Julie Vallimont (computer, piano, synths, accordion, jawharp) and Noah VanNorstrand (fiddle, foot percussion, didgeridoo, vocals). They'll "create live sonic landscapes that’ll put you in a dance trance" -- bettah believe it. We are excited to be back at the Cambridge Community Center at: 5 Callender St, Cambridge, MA 02139.

**** Please note the different TIME and LOCATION! We don't want anyone getting lost! ******** This is a special contra dance with live electronic-acoustic music and special club lighting. As always, BIDA is an inclusive community and everyone is welcome. And if you bring a friend who's new to BIDA, you'll both get free passes to a future dance! The Cambridge Community Center is just a few blocks from Central Square on the Red Line, and has limited street parking around it. We highly encourage public transit and carpooling -- feel free to start a carpool thread in the comments below! Parking is difficult. If at all possible we recommend that you take the T and walk to event. If you are coming from far away you should drive to Alewife and park in the garage there, take the redline to Central Square, and walk to the dance. If you need to park in central your best option is one of the five pay and display lots in the square. They will fill up.

Admission will be $7 - $15 sliding scale.

See you there!

results.description:
The Oregon Fail combines the adventure and whimsy of an improvised period comedy with a format based on one of the most popular video games of all time. The legends of Oregon describe that land as full of opportunities, wealth and wonder, but a cast of brave and decidedly expendable improvisers are going to show that the trail to get there is rife with audience-created danger. An all-powerful Player will prompt the audience to make key decisions along the trail, determining how obstacles such as rivers, disease and bandits will be faced by the wagon crew. In between those decision points, the improvisers interact, hunt an ever dwindling buffalo population, and talk about the vast riches they will one day have, should they ever make it to Oregon...

Tickets here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/the-oregon-fail-you-have-died-of-comedy-tickets-18230305334
results.name: The Oregon Fail: You Have Died of Comedy

group.name: Boston-area Comedy Lovers - Comedy shows for free (or cheap)

results.description:
Chef and owner Pankaj Pradhan, owner and operator of Red Lentil Vegan & Vegetarian Restaurant in Watertown, has openedWild Rice Vegan Cafe, a breakfast and lunch multi-fusion restaurant.

The grand opening of Wild Rice Vegan Cafe will be held on Friday, January 29, and Saturday, January 30, from 6 AM to 3 PM each day. 

The event will feature an all-you-can-eat buffet of exclusive Wild Rice vegan breakfast and lunch dishes, from 11 AM - 2 PM. 

Guests will also be able to pick up coupons and enter to win gift cards from Wild Rice, Red Lentil, and other area businesses. 

For complete details, please check out the official press release:http://bit.ly/wrlaunch­ 

Phone: [masked] 
Address: 71 Elm Street at Monroe Avenue, Watertown, MA 02472 (address for the now-closed Grappa) 

WiFi equipped.

It's on the #70 MBTA bus route.

Read about the Wild Rice Vegan Cafe (and see photos): 
http://boston.eater.com/2015/12/14/10104088/wild-rice-vegan-cafe-watertown-open 

http://boston.eater.com/2015/7/21/9008809/red-lentil-renovations-new-vegan-venture-2015 

http://boston.eater.com/2015/12/14/10104088/wild-rice-vegan-cafe-watertown-open 

Wild Rice Vegan Cafe - 71 Elm Street, Watertown, MA 
Locally sourced vegan world cuisine in a casual café environment. Wild Rice offers vegan breakfast and lunch, cold-pressed fresh juices, smoothies, and coffee at the counter. Many dishes are gluten-free and soy-free. Patrons enjoy quick carry-out service or dine-in in a relaxed, well-lit seating area. Free Wi-fi is available. Wild Rice is regularly open seven days per week: for breakfast from 6–11 AM and for lunch from 11 AM–3 PM. They offer off-site catering and rent their space for groups of up to 45. 

Red Lentil Vegan & Vegetarian Restaurant - 600 Mount Auburn Street, Watertown, MAOpened in 2009. Red Lentil hosts charity and vegan-related community events like the Boston Vegetarian Society Annual Harvest Dinner and showcases food at local area events like the Boston Local Food Festival, Boston Greenfest, and the Taste of WGBH Food & Wine Festival. It’s a more traditional, sit-down space for lunch, dinner, and brunch. The menu offers both vegan and vegetarian world cuisine. Also offerings catering and space rental. Winner: 2013 TripAdvisor Certificate of Excellence, 2013 Nature’s Plate Award (Nature Conservancy). 
Well-reviewed:  http://theredlentil.com/press 

Chef Pankaj Pradhan 
Chef grew up vegetarian in Kolkata and, after working as a chef for both Hyatt Hotels and Carnival Cruise Lines, he completed his culinary training in France. He has visited over 40 countries. 

He moved to NYC to work at an Indian restaurant, but he learned that it wasn’t ideal for his world-cuisine background. 

He relocated to Rhode Island where he worked at a vegetarian restaurant and, mid-2009, moved to Boston and opened Red Lentil.

In 2014, Pradhan began a partnership with Harvard University Dining Services. He trained dining staff and introduced vegan cuisine as a dining option for university students.

And in 2015, he opened his second Watertown restaurant: Wild Rice Vegan Cafe.
results.name: Grand Opening: Wild Rice Vegan Cafe

results.description:
Join us for our weekly weekend run! We'll be meeting in Back Bay and logging some miles around Boston. All paces and runner levels are welcome! 

During the winter months, we'll be meeting at the Boston Marathon RunBase on Boylston street for our Saturday runs. They have lockers and showers available for your use though you'll need to provide your own lock if you plan to use a locker. 

Please post your desired pace and distance when you RSVP. 

There are three different distance options this weekend (although they can be modified for intermediate distances), a 5.5 mile, a 9.5 mile, and a 12 mile route. All routes start by heading east on Boylston before heading south on Arlington. They then take a tour of the South End, taking Tremont to Union Park, then continuing southwest on Washington (with a loop of Blackstone Square). At Dudley Square the shorter route heads north on Malcolm X Boulevard and then heads east through the Southwest Corridor Park all the way to Dartmouth Street. The two long routes continue south onto Warren Street and make their way to Franklin Park with the 12 mile route doing almost a full loop and the 9.5 mile route cutting straight across. All routes end back at RunBase. 5.5 Mile Route: http://www.gmap-pedometer.com/?r=6788473
9.5 Mile Route: http://www.gmap-pedometer.com/?r=6789554
12 Mile Route: http://www.gmap-pedometer.com/?r=6789548
results.name: Whippets Weekend Run

group.name: Dashing Whippets Running Team - Boston Chapter

results.description:
We will run down Comm Ave in the carriage lane to the Chestnut Hill/BC reservoir, with the option to run around the reservoir before turning around. This is an out and back course so the distance is flexible - you can run however many miles you want!  There are some hills - we will run 3 of the 4 Newton Hills along the Boston Marathon course (if you go at least 8 miles - 4 out and 4 back).

Meet outside at the tables next to Bruegger's and the ATM.  We will leave right at 8:30 AM (especially when it is cold out!).

The pace will vary depending on who shows up.  If there is a wide range of paces, we frequently end up splitting into smaller groups based on pace.  Even if your pace doesn't "match up" with anyone else, meeting up with the group and starting the run with everyone is a great way to get yourself out of bed on those early Saturday mornings!
results.name: Comm Ave long run  8-15+ miles

results.description:
Event Organizer: Michael Blair @ (978)[masked]

01/18 - This event listing has been updated to reflect the finalized plans. I will be adding people who indicated that Isolation was their choice. Group size is limited to 10 (both because that number seems to work good in the winter and the fact that we will be traveling within a Wilderness Protection Area that limits group size to 10) so if you can't make it please change your RSVP to NO so that others can join.

=====

Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event.

Answers DO NOT carry over from one event to another so you must answer them for EACH EVENT. Also, questions might not show up if you RSVP from a phone or tablet so if you don't see them you will need to use a computer.

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself and others at risk. Consider this before you RSVP.

=== What We're Doing ===

The plan is to hike to one of the 4,000 footers in New Hampshire - Isolation. We will use Rocky Branch Trail, Engine Hill Bushwhack, Isolation Trail, and Davis Path to reach the summit. From there we will turn around and retrace our steps back to the parking lot.

If you are interested in participating in this event sign up for the waiting list. I will add people that (1) answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process and (2) have done similar hikes within the past three months.

RSVPs close 24 hours before the event.

The maximum group size for this trip will be 10 people. 

Guests aren't permitted.

Dogs are only permitted with prior approval of the event organizer.

=== Trip Summary ===

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you. 

On this moderate pace (~2.0 MPH) trip we will hike about 12.5 miles and climb about 3,400 feet. It should take an average hiker about 8 hours to complete (this duration does not include time for breaks). This event is considered INTERMEDIATE because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain.

Use this link for more information about where we are going and how we will get there:

• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/47-Mt-Isolation-4004


Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants. 

Use this link for the current weather forecast:

• http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=44.2147877750005&lon=-71.30923773199964#.Vp0WwTawlrU

=== What to Bring === 

Don't wear ANY cotton - this includes your socks and underwear. You will need winter hiking boots - if you wear them in the summer they aren't designed for winter use (e.g. insulation). You will need mountaineering snow shoes. Not all snowshoes are the same - some are designed for steep terrain with potentially deep snow while others aren't. These are the acceptable brands and models:

• Tubbs Flex ALP, Flex VRT, Flex TRK, or Mountaineers.

• MSR Lightening, Revo, or Evo. 

• TSL Symbioz Elite or Expert. 

• Atlas Aspect, Endeavor, or Series 10/11/12.

You will also need traction - while you can bring mountaineering crampons if you want I think all you will need is either Kahtoola Microspikes or Hillsound Trail Crampons. DO NOT BRING IMITATION SPIKES OR ANY FORM OF YAK TRAX.

Use this link for a list of items needed for a winter day hike: 

• </a><a href="http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf">http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

=== Directions ===

We will meet at the Rocky Branch Trailhead which is located on the west side of Route 16 south of the AMC's Pinkham Notch Visitor's Center near Jackson, NH. According to Google Maps this spot is about 155 miles from Boston and it should take about 2 hours 55 minutes to drive there.

Use this link to customize the driving directions:

• https://goo.gl/maps/on3mNrQDrdB2

</a>

While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride.

=== Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer ===

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the <a href="http://www.hikesafe.com/">Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.
results.how_to_find_us: Gray Toyota Highlander or Maroon Honda Accord.
results.name: NH4K ... U Picked It - Isolation

results.description:
Their major issue is that they have tons of donations, and not even close enough amount of volunteers, to sort useable vs. recycle goods.  

http://thewishproject.org/ 

The Wish Project is a non-profit dedicated to providing free furniture, home goods, baby goods, and clothing to people in need in the Merrimack Valley, primarily through reuse and recycling. They serve thousands of people each year, and rely on the help of many volunteers. Let's be some of those volunteers! We'll take on whatever task they need on this day, but generally it involves sorting and organizing donations so they can be given out to clients. Children ages 8+ are welcome to join the effort. It's a great opportunity to teach your kids compassion in a very hands-on way. 

IMPORTANT:

If you are bringing children, please make a note in the comments section so I can give the Wish Project an accurate count of adults and kids who will be attending.

http://thewishproject.org/

 *PLEASE NOTE:  When you RSVP 'yes' it becomes a commitment. I am in contact with the volunteer coordinator, Patty, whom is now a member, giving her a head count. She then creates a list of things that need to be done -relying upon the number of volunteers. If your plans change, please be considerate -take a moment to update your RSVP to 'no.' It's very simple- and greatly appreciated! Thanks :)
results.how_to_find_us: The WORD is out, n' spreading!
results.name: Giving Back aka Volunteering @ The Wish Project - Lowell

results.description:
Hey, 

We're pushing you up the ladder. 

We'd like to invite you for a BIG Data & Hadoop 2.x Foundation Course featuring 6 hours of live training, 4 hours of practicals, 2 installation guides and 1 question bank to give you the perfect foundation. The following will be covered: 

• Complete Hadoop Stack - System Configurations & Dataflows

• Data Loading via HDFS - Name Node & Data Node

• BIG Data Analytics via MapReduce - Mapper, Reducer and Combiner

• Running Queries via HiveQL; Complier & UDFs

• What is YARN? YARN and HDFS Integration? 

It is scheduled for January 30th and 31st; 9:00AM to 12:00PM. 

The registration fee for this course in only 43USD for the first 33 slots; after that the pricing will increase to 99USD. This is our second edition; the 1st one was sold out. :) 

Click here to register at 43USD. 

If you require any assistance, please click on the above link. You'll get all the details. 

Cheers!
results.name: BIG Data & Hadoop 2.x Foundation Course

results.description:
We had a great success last year with our Evaluation Workshop, so we've decided to do it again! Please join us for this special 5th-Saturday meeting of the Watertown Saturday Toastmasters. We'll have members from other clubs give speeches, then our club members will form Evaluation Teams with different areas of focus. Please sign up for an Evaluation Team today at our club site.

Note: If you've never attended Toastmasters before and want to see what a "regular meeting" is like, please join us on February 6th. 

Evaluation Workshop

Workshop leader:  Jeanne McDermott

The most challenging role as a Toastmaster is evaluating another members speech. The goal is not only to give a concise presentation but valuable feedback.

This workshop will offer opportunities as a team (and individually) to develop keener skills in the complex process of listening, writing and presenting an effective evaluation

watertownsaturdaytoastmasters.org

Join us for a snowshoe/ski at Rocky Woods Reservation, one of the best snowshoe and cross-country ski locations in Eastern Massachusetts.  Wide paths and open woods wind around several man-made ponds, and ascend a gentle slope that overlooks the area.

If there isn't enough snow to snowshoe or ski, we'll hike.

This is a Trustees site, parking is $4 for non-members, free if you are a Trustees member.

Activity Level:  Moderate

What to Bring:  Snowshoes or skis, sunglasses or goggles, weather appropriate clothing, hat, gloves, water for 3 hours, snacks.

results.description:
This Saturday there's a special surprise that awaits us, so come join us at 9am! Same place, same great group of people... and hopefully some new faces too! :)

Every Saturday morning at 10:00 AM we gather for a fun, calming group run at the Chestnut Hill Reservoir. Both walkers and runners are welcome. Our main goal is to socialize and support one another!

The Boston Bulldogs is a co-ed non-profit running club founded to support those battling addiction and in recovery, those who have been affected by addiction and their supporters.

We welcome and encourage runners of all levels – dreamers, beginners, as well as those with running experience, past or present. Our volunteer runners will be there to coach you at your current level, and help you meet your goals. We might even be able to help with running gear if needed. 

We meet twice weekly at the Chestnut Hill Reservoir (Cleveland Circle/Reservoir Green Line C or D train) -- on Saturday mornings at 10:00 AM and Thursday evenings at 6:30 PM. We first gather in front of the Cleveland Circle Starbucks, before heading over to the reservoir. See you there!

If you are interested in becoming a member or a volunteer, in making a contribution to the Club, in sponsoring a runner in recovery, or in learning more about the Boston Bulldog educational wellness/running program, contact us at:

• Website - BostonBulldogsRunning.com

• Email - [masked] 

• Phone -[masked]
results.how_to_find_us: We will start gathering outside the Starbucks at Cleveland Circle around 8:45am... see you then!
results.name: Saturday's Group Fun Run & Surprise!

results.description:
Free Parking: In the designated spaces across the street from the Reservation Headquarters (695 Hillside Street, Milton) or at Houghtons’ Pond (40 Hillside St, Milton, MA). Please allow 15 minutes to park, gather your gear and meet at the Hillside Street Reservation HQ. We will start walking about shortly after 9:15. 

This hike is challenging, with many hills to ascend on a rocky, sometimes narrow and steep trail. As the name implies, though, the Skyline Trail takes you along the many Reservation ridges, offering scenic vistas. (You may have to use your imagination in inclement weather). We will make two loops - figure 8 - from the Park Reservation Headquarters. 

The first loop will follow some of the choicest sections of the Skyline Trail to Route 28 (Randolph Ave.) and return to Park HQ along the Bugbee Path. The second loop will ascend Hancock Hill, Hemenway Hill and Wolcott Hill before you head for Great Blue Hill. You will return to Park HQ via the lower Skyline trail. 

You will have a bail-out option before the second loop. Each loop is 3-4 miles. The hike organizer will go at a moderate pace with stops at trail junctions and occasional photo ops. Total distance about 8 miles, circa 4-5 hours.

Apres hike at the Turnpike Cafe, 958 Turnpike Street Canton, MA.

Traction devices such as Kahtoola MICROspikes Footwear Traction or equal are often necessary for winter hiking. Please bring them.

On top of the hills the weather can be surprisingly windy. We will not linger long when it is, but please be prepared with appropriate clothing in your pack.

Pets on a leash.

Please read the following Pages Tabs prior to participating on an event.
Responsibilities of Participants
Courtesies and Expectations
results.name: Blue Hills Choice Skyline 8 Hike

results.description:
Note:  Pose will be the same as the Friday 4-hour sessions, so if you want to get a REALLY long pose, sign up for both.  Model is Nathalie.

Jeremy Durling will host- Jeremy's paintings are available through the Sloane Merrill Gallery on Charles Street in Boston.  

Members (those paying the $25 monthly membership fee) may reserve a spot for $55, non-members for $65.    Three hours each Saturday morning, 9:30-12:30.  You can come individual days by paying $15 (members) or $25 (non-members) for a single drop-in, but please consider paying for the full amount and committing to come!  It will help us to keep these long sessions going, and even if you pay for the whole session and don't come to all of them (often happens), you're getting a pretty square deal.  If you would like to pay online please do so at

http://damonlehrer.com/damonlehrer.com/payment.html


PLEASE TRY TO BE ON TIME-  folks who come later than 10:00 am will be admitted ONLY at the convenience of the host (who is busy painting). PLEASE NOTE THE PRICES BELOW- They are deliberately a bit higher than for drawing sessions as we keep the studio less crowded for painting, and it's more work to put together a four week pose.  

----- IF THE CAPACITY REACHES 12, whether or not that number shows up on the RSVP list, we may have to close the session to further drop-ins to preserve breathing space for those who reserved ahead. ------

 Please consider that for $55 or $65 (non-member) you can reserve ahead for the whole month, which helps us stay open for business.  If you want to drop in, you can RSVP and pay online- simply change the amount of the payment at the payment stage to reflect the drop-in rate above.

results.description:
Originally part of a village of  “Praying Indians”  who converted to Christianity after being proselytized by 17th-century Puritan  preacher John Eliot (see illustration below), Natick’s Broadmoor Wildlife Sanctuary offers 9 miles of peaceful  hiking  through 624  acres of woods, eskers, orchards, cascades and pastures along the Charles River and Indian Brook. It’s  a great locale for a mellow winter trek in the suburbs.


We’ll plan on an approximately 6.5 -mile loop hike  of interconnecting trails including the Indian Brook Trail, Glacial Hill Trail, Boundary Trail,  Blueberry Swamp Loop, Little Farm Pond Loop. Charles River Loop,Marsh Trail, and Quacking Frog Trail. However, this is subject to change depending upon trail conditions, temperature, and precipitation. You’ll need to be prepared with either Kahtoola MICROspikes or Hillsound Trail crampons. No Yaktrax, Stabilicers, or other substitutes please.

    The Old Orchard at Broadmoor by MABA resident          artist Barry Van Duse  

If snow cover is sufficient, we’ll make this a snowshoeing event. You can rent snowshoes through REI or EMS. Check out the followingnlinks for more info:  http://www.rei.com/stores/rentals.html#massachusetts


http://www.ems.com/link-page?cid=retail-services

We’ll meet in the parking area. Trail fee  is $5.00 for non MA Audubon Society members. You can purchase a membership @ the Sanctuary nature center.

                                     Photo by Alison M. 

What you need to know:


Terrain Difficulty: This terrain rates  “Easy” because it is mostly flat. although the  trails at Broadmoor have roots, rocks and rough terrain in some places. The leaves underfoot are wet and slippery. Trail sections might be flooded or covered with ice.

Although  "Easy"  hikes are generally suitable for beginning hikers who keep  fit doing other exercise, this may present a challenge to some due to winter conditions.  Please be sure that you can comfortably handle 7 miles in the snow, ice and/or water.

Remember that the Difficulty Rating is for the terrain; not the hike itself. When determining if a hike is right for you, remember to factor in: terrain, distance, estimated pace, duration, weather prediction, driving time and your fitness level as well as your mood and frustration threshold.

Distance: Approximately 6.5 miles.

Elevation Gain: 50’ @ most

Hike Time: Estimated 3.5 hours. However, this is an estimate. Actual times vary greatly according to weather, trail conditions and the group itself. Don't sign up if you've scheduled something later in the day. The Organizer is not responsible for getting you back in time.

Anticipated Pace: 2-2.5 mph or the pace of the slowest hiker

Hike Type:  Loop

There is no way of knowing trail conditions ahead of time. Use your own judgement.

Individuals with recurrent "No Shows" , who routinely drop out, who have given us a hard time or about whom we have received complaints from fellow Trekkers will not be accepted. If you haven't hiked with us before, add yourself to the list if you can avoid falling into one of those categories.

Please don't RSVP "Yes" unless you really intend to come. We are committed to being there for you. If you are not equally committed to being there (e.g. You're waiting to get off another hike's wait list) then please don't sign up.

Please do not show up for an event unexpected or unprepared. Bring water (2 liters), hiking boots (not sneakers or trailrunners), microspikes and snacks. Protect yourself against deer ticks and dress in layers to keep yourself warm.

This is winter hiking season. Bring your Kahtoola MICROspikes or Hillsound Trail crampons (not YakTrax or Stabilicers) even if it hasn't snowed. Ice can form even at moderate elevations or in thicker woods on flat terrain. You can purchase them at REI or EMS.

Read "Winter Day Hiking Essentials"in the Pages before signing up  all winter hikes in cold weather conditions.

We hike in light rain or light snow, but heavy rain or snow or any  extreme weather that renders hiking and/or driving conditions hazardous cancels.

This is a group event and participants are expected to follow the lead, stay together, stop at junctions or summits, and support all participants should circumstances require teamwork. We start together and finish together. If you decide to leave the group at any time, you are on your own.

No dogs and no guests are allowed on hikes. Have your guest join the group so they can agree to the liability waiver and attend an event.

Please remember that your Event Organizers  are volunteers, the event is free and we are all adults. The people who have the best times on these hikes are those who stay loose and roll with things as they happen. If you are expecting Daniel Boone as your leader, you’re barking up the wrong tree. If you need everything to run perfectly, this hike is not for you.

Short Version: This not an event for high-maintenance individuals.

By signing up and/or attending this hike you agree to the Liability Waiver Below:  

Remember: Your Event Organizers  are volunteers. You are solely responsible for your own safety and enjoyment. As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you know and will follow the Hiker Responsibility Code described at <a>www.hikesafe.com;</a> you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; the organizer(s) of this activity is a volunteer; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reason.

If you are offering or need a ride, post that on the message board. However, when responding please do so privately by clicking on the person's profile pick and clicking the "message" link.

When making carpooling arrangements, please keep them private and  off the Message Board. For your own safety don't post your phone number.

For more info go to:

results.description:
We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (circa[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

See you there!

results.description:
How to find us: Inside the clubhouse is a table with registration forms. I will be waiting next to the table. If you have trouble finding us, call/text me. I will email DETAILS including my cell phone number to yes RSVPs the night before the event.


The Activity

The have groomed ski tracks - many of them form loops. We can go on these tracks as one group (or break up into smaller groups, depending on how many RSVP). Price for one day is $13 trail pass plus $18 ski rental - links with details below.

Location details: http://www.skiboston.com/skitrack


Trail pass price information:  http://www.mass.gov/eea/agencies/dcr/massparks/recreational-activities/leo-j-martin-ski-track.html

The ski rental information can be found at the link below. If this is your first time, I would suggest the touring skis (not the skate skis).

http://www.skiboston.com/skitrack/rates.php

They have beginning tracks to practice. These (about ten) flat straight beginning tracks are about 100 feet long - and parallel to each other. These are freely available for your use, but I personally don’t have enough time to help everyone.

Also, they have beginner skis lessons (which require a reservation). If you decide to take lessons, it would be separate from the group activity.

http://www.skiboston.com/skitrack/skischool/adult_lessons.php

UPDATE: For people taking the classes, the rest of group will be on the trails. But the trails are loops, some small, some big. The loops don't take that long to do. We can try to sync up after the class is over. The trail map can be found here: http://www.skiboston.com/skitrack/trailmap.php I'm guessing we will probably be on the loops in the "Lighted Snowmaking Area" and the "John Hart Track". Considering the number of people, we will have more than one group.

After Event, Food and Drinks:

I will update with suggestions for food and drinks.

RSVP Responsibility!


Only RSVP if you can go and update your RSVP (don't wait until the day of the event) if you can't make it.

I am only a volunteer. I will be waiting at the starting point, and I will be expecting you. I look forward to meeting you.

* No pets allowed on hike.

* Members only. No guests permitted.

* Members must have a valid photo.

Dress:

* Dress appropriately for the weather conditions.

* Dress in layers as needed.

* Non-cotton clothing works best.  

* Bring water, snacks and any personal medicines and gear you may need as well.

FOUL WEATHER CANCELS.

You assume all risk associated with this activity.

Liability Waiver: As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hiker Responsibility Code described at <a>www.hikesafe.com;</a> the leader(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify the leader(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.

Directions to the Event

See this link for directions:

http://www.skiboston.com/skitrack/directions.php

If the main large parking lot is full (possible on very busy days), look for signs for alternative parking options. In the past, they have provided van pickups from the next side street parking.

results.description:
(a set of 6 Saturday classes)


Always wanted to learn how they really fought in the middle ages? Forget any ideas about crude battering on armour; the successful warrior strikes to the gaps and the openings of his or her opponent's attacks, and supplements this with disarms, throws, and other techniques which secure the advantage over larger or stronger attackers.

Around the year 1400, Fiore dei Liberi trained medieval knights and squires, and authored multiple books of medieval combat, some of which have survived to the present day. His method, L'Arte d'Armizare (the Art of Bearing Arms), shows an integrated and cross-referenced system of sword, dagger, grappling, spear & lance, pollaxe and other weapons on foot and on horseback, with and without armour, and easily dispels any illusions that medieval combat was about unskilled strength.

Our beginners' course is six linked classes that give the basic techniques and vocabulary of L'Arte, and enables men and women to begin regular unarmoured training and learning.  No prior training needed; all class equipment is provided.

So, come join the scholars and combatants of our company!

(The price shown is for the set of all six classes (Jan 9, 16, 23, 30, Feb 6 and 13) and membership and registration.  Classes are not offered separately.  We'll send an email with some class materials before the first session.)
