results.description:
Think of this as a creative mini-retreat. It's designed primarily for writers—of all experience levels, working in any genre. Be aware that we will spend most of the day working together in silence. People working in art journals are welcome to attend, but will be asked to work quietly as well. Although we've booked the space for 6 hours, you're welcome to arrive and leave whenever you like. 

WHAT WE'LL DO: 

• 11:30 a.m.: Doors open.

• 12:15 p.m.: Write to easy creative prompts (if there's interest). 

• 1 p.m. sharp: Begin writing (or creating).

Although we'll be in the same large room, we'll be writing in companionable silence, talking only during breaks. If you'd like to have a conversation with someone, you're welcome to step outside or head to a nearby coffee shop.


• About 4:15-4:30 p.m.: People will be invited to briefly share from their work, if they wish. (Sharing is optional and time will be limited.) No one will critique anyone's work unless the writer requests feedback. 

• 5:30 p.m.: Clean up and depart. 

AMENITIES: The Braintree Community Arts Center is a newly converted two-story house about 3.5 miles south of South Shore Plaza on the road (Route 37). We'll have the house all to ourselves for the day. It's bright, pleasant, and equipped with tables, chairs, restrooms, a coffeemaker, a fridge, a countertop range, free parking, and Wi-Fi. I will provide a few books for inspiration, and an extension cord and power strip for power.

WHAT TO BRING: Yourself, your writing projects and writing implements (computer or  writing notebook and pen, or journal). Bring your own beverage. Feel free to bring a snack to share—but that’s entirely optional.

COST: $15 (cash or check), regardless of how long you stay. This goes toward space-use costs and our Meetup fee.  

HOW TO RESERVE A SPOT: RSVP "yes" using Meetup's RSVP function. The RSVP list is our official headcount for the day, so it's the only way to sign up—emailing the organizer or posting messages on the site won't hold a spot.

CANCELLATIONS: If we need to cancel due to weather or any other reason, we'll post a message on the Web site and e-mail all "yes" RSVPs as far in advance as possible. 

REMINDER ABOUT ABOUT RSVPs: Your RSVP is a reservation, and we're trusting that you'll honor it. If you can't make it, please change your RSVP from "yes" to "no" at least 24 hours in advance. If you cancel with less than 24 hours notice, or if you RSVP "yes" and then don't show up, you'll be asked to pay the fee anyway to help cover our costs for the day. 

Looking forward to seeing you!
results.name: Meet to write (or work on art journals) in companionable silence

results.description:
For Tickets: http://bit.ly/1Pq3tOQ

A Font That's Just Your Type! Whether you're an aspiring designer or whether creating your very own font just sounds really cool to you (because it definitely is), this workshop will suit you perfectly.

Our instructor Elijah will walk you through the basics of using an opensource software called FontForge - here, you'll focus on the building block letters: H, D, O, S, n, p and o. Designing these letters will give you the ability to create your own fonts for a while to come. At 4PM you'll leave the workshop with two things: the knowledge that you just gained a way cool skill that expands a huge range of creative options, and secondly, your own font that's just your type. ALL levels welcome, no prerequisites required. Please download FontForge before attending.
Please bring a laptop, a pen, and paper. If you need us to provide you with a laptop, please get in touch with [masked] so that we can accommodate you. We look forward to seeing you there!

Also check us out at:
http://dangerawesome.com
https://twitter.com/danger_awesome
https://www.facebook.com/gotlasers?
https://instagram.com/dangerawesome/
http://www.yelp.com/biz/danger-awesome-cambridge-2
Help support us and become a member at:
http://www.dangerawesome.co/membership/

FAQs

-What are my transport/parking options getting to the event?-

You can either take the red line to the Central Square stop, and find us on Mass Ave and Prospect St., or you can park in Lot 5 on Bishop Allen Dr., right behind H-Mart.

-Where can I contact the organizer with any questions?-

At [masked]! -Do I have to bring my printed ticket to the event?-

Either a printed ticket, or an up-to-date ID with your full name.

-What is the refund policy?-

results.description:
Vanessa Zoltan will talk about how we can ritualize conversations about art and meaningful activities. She will share some of the practices and lessons that she has practiced through her work with Harry Potter as a Sacred Text.

Vanessa is the Assistant Humanist Chaplain at Harvard and the Humanist Hub.

With special guest Bob Filbin: Bob is Chief Data Scientist at Crisis Text Line, the first large-scale 24/7 national crisis line for teens on the medium they use and trust most: texting. Bob specializes in the application of behavioral psychology to questions of data collection, analysis, and reporting, to make sure data leads to strategic actions. Bob has given keynote lectures on using data to drive behavioral change at the YMCA National CIOs Conference, NFAR Summit, and SXSW. He has written for the Harvard Business Review and Medium, and was named one of the Chronicle of Philanthropy’s 40 Under 40 in 2016 who are making their mark in the nonprofit world. He lives and plays Quidditch in NYC.

Childcare is available at this and all events. Please email [masked] to reserve a spot!

results.description:
SPECIAL NOTE: I just got a brand-new copy of 1856 and will be looking to try that one out. 

18xx games are about railroads: building track and running trains for profit. 18xx games are also about a stock market, and the skullduggery between various robber barons as they try to build, thwart, take over, or bankrupt companies. But, they can take quite a while to play. We play with poker chips and emphasize a "ready to play" culture (meaning you're ready to act when your company is up). Games have generally taken from 2 hours (via bankruptcy) to 6 hours (to the end) with the average around 5 hours, even with new players. The more you plan in advance, the faster the game (of course, many times the other robber barons thwart your plans!)

You will need to be ready to start right at the starting time, or very close to it, because the game is so long. We also are splitting into two games quite frequently now so being early is better so we can decide which 18xx games to play and then have to set them up, unless we ALL can come to a pre-arrangement in the comments.

New players are welcome although we strongly suggest familiarizing yourself with the basic rules and concepts first. A brand new player will need 20 to 40 minutes of rules explanation before they play. The game really isn't overly complex, rules-wise, it's just long with lots of decisions. It is a little fiddly sometimes, though.

Due to some late arrivals in prior months, we will emphasize: If you're over 15 minutes late and have not made arrangements with one of the tables, you are probably only going to be a mere spectator, unless there is a game doing a rules explanation, you know that 18xx variant well, and can make it before it starts. If you're much later you probably won't be able to join a game at all. It usually takes us all afternoon and well into the evening to play one game of 18xx. Even our more "experienced" tables usually drop four or five hours into a single game (or more; last month we didn't finish either 1835 or 1830 until 9:30 PM or later). It is rare that there is a second game.

Also since we usually know the people in the week or so prior it will be good at that point if we can sort out what games we want to play in advance. While it's no guarantee we can break down that way, knowing to set up something in advance is SUPER helpful and time saving. Setting up and teaching a new 18xx variant can take an hour or more and the games are quite long as it is, so every little bit helps. What you need to know about 334 Mass Ave:

-Press 999 on the intercom and security will let you into the building
-You must sign in at the security desk with a picture ID
-Take the elevator down to level "A." Exit the elevator to your left and the community room will be ahead on your right, next to the laundry room.
results.name: Train Hard: January 18xx Event

results.description:
What do Germans, Swedes, Fins, Norwegians, Russians, Danes, Canadians and the Swiss have in common? They all learned to ice skate growing up. Come on out on a Sunday afternoon to the Boston Common Frog Pond for an afternoon of ice skating in the beautiful outdoors.

Another European invention, a study at the University of Oxford suggests that the earliest ice skating happened in southern Finland more than 3000 years ago as an energy-saving strategy to get from one icy place to another.

Parents, feel free to bring the kids. And don't be shy if you have never skated before yourselves, come try it out. With many that do know how to skate, we will teach you. There are many discounts, specials, and family plans out there. Keep looking at the messages on this event and your e-mails, I will forward them as I find them.

We will be joined by EuroProvidence - The Rhode Island Social European Network, the Boston Euro Social Meetup Group and the Québec Meetup Group in what will surely be a Frozen United Nations Skating Day. So sharpen those skates, get your winter toque with a pom-pom out, and join us for a fun, wintery afternoon, Scandinavian style.

Afterwards, we can all decide where to go for a hot chocolate, glühwein or shot of grappa to warm up. We'll make that call on the day of.

Above: Scandinavian sweaters.

********************************************************

Announcement: All, I will not be able to make it there by 2:00PM, so Eniola will be meeting and greeting before we disperse. Also, if you entered artwork into our first art show, we will have it available for pick up by 2:30PM!

********************************************************

Hi All!

Let's do sketching, cafe edition! For this meet up, I will be in Cafe Algiers, but feel free to choose any cafe in Harvard square. We will meet back in Cafe Algiers to share our work. 

Harvard has a plethora of cafe, where students and locals alike come to relax, talk, and study. These cafes also have distinct architecture and design as well a great people watching. Cafe Algiers has a unique minaret feature, reminiscent of the mosque calling tower. 

Other cafes include Cafe Pamploma, which was one of Harvard's first coffee houses. It has mention in a variety of media outlets and has been relatively unchanged since the 80's. Cafe Crema which is a popular spot that specializes in coffee and sweets. 

So come join us for a cup of coffee or tea and some sketching. Hope to see you there!

-Miriam

results.description:
Note: this is not a meetup, but a ticket offer only:

Cantata Singers will present the complete version of George Frideric Handel’s beloved 1783 oratorio, Israel in Egypt. Often performed with only the second and third movements, Cantata Singers restores the deeply personal music of Part 1 to this audience favorite. One of Handel’s most revered works, Israel in Egypt is a masterful recounting of the deliverance of the Israelites from bondage. With its uncommonly varied and thrilling choral and orchestral music, Israel in Egypt shows some of Handel’s most powerful and inventive writing for vocal ensemble. 

Go to http://www.cantatasingers.org/season/january-2016/and use code MeetUp1516 at checkout to get 20% off tickets.

From 2 to 4 PM we will have an advanced level meetup at the Cambridge Recreational Center in Cambridge. There will be one court (12 spots) available. The game will be on a men's height net.

This game is for Yankee C+ and above level only (college club level or better). Players are required to know how to play a 6-2 and 5-1 formation.

If you'd like to play, please send an email to Brian using this URL: http://www.meetup.com/volleyball-122/message/?recipientId=4774008<a href="http://www.meetup.com/volleyball-122/message/?recipientId=4774008"></a>

In the email, confirm that you know how to play in a 5-1 or 6-2 offense, and mention your preferred position (if any).

Players will be added to the list to fill up positions. This game is intended for Yankee C+ and above players (or equivalent), and people who have not been no-shows at previous meetups. There is a strict cap to make sure everyone gets lots of playing time. Note that sending an email does not guarantee a spot to play; spots are only guaranteed if you receive a positive confirmation email. The cost of the meetup will be $5. Please pay the organizer when you arrive before the meetup starts. The money goes to cover the cost of the court rental. The entrance to the gym is on Cambridge Street opposite Harvard Market. The nearest intersection to the entrance is Cambridge Street and Roberts Road. The nearest T stop is Harvard Square. The gym is about a ten minute walk from the T stop. Parking near the school on Sundays is generally easy to find, as meters and residential parking rules are generally not enforced on Sundays (parking signs should say "EX SUNDAY" or similar).

From the beating drums to the splashing paint to the sensory surprises at every turn, the Blue Man Group experience is wildly intense and totally unique. The show combines comedy, music and technology -- but no words -- to create a pulsing rhythm that unites people of all ages, languages and cultures in a spirit of joy. Reviewers describe it as "visually stunning," "wildly inventive," and "hysterically funny" -- and audiences often come away speechless, with a huge smile on their faces. WHY SHOULD YOU COME?

3. Listen to free live Bluegrass bands5. Make announcements about other upcoming happenings6. Bring promotional materials to handout!

results.description:
It's hard to believe that the first month of 2016 is almost over. Before we know it, it'll be spring and then summer, and new, lighter projects will come out of the closets - lacy shawls, cotton tops, summer cardigans... did you know that you can even knit a bikini??? Now is the time to finish up those last winter projects - hats, scarfs and cowls, and heavy, cozy sweaters. I love to work on my projects with my wonderful group of knitting friends, and I always look forward to our Sunday gatherings. 

Our next session is a week from tomorrow, and there are still spaces available, so please, sign up, and I can assure you that you will be welcome by everyone, and that you will have lots of fun. 

My regulars already know where I live, but for the new members, my house is almost at the fork where Franklin Street joins Nahant Street. It's a blue (or gray, depending on the light) duplex with a porch in the front and an American flag hanging over it. Please keep in mind that I share my driveway with my neighbor, so parking in the driveway is limited. There are plenty of parking  spaces on my street and, if need be, on the surrounding streets, so you should not have any problems finding a spot. 

SEE YOU ALL ON SUNDAY, January 31st, at 3 PM!
results.name: Meet up for our crafts again

We will meet while it is still light out to do some street photography, then we can do some night photography for those who wish to stay after nightfall. Dress warmly, but there should be plenty of places to step inside to warm up if it gets too cold. I will probably leave my tripod in the car until it starts to get dark as to be less encumbered. 

One parking option is the Harvard Square Parking garage, which costs $15 to park for more than 90 mins on a Sunday. Some businesses will give validations to save an additional $2. Municipal Lot #2 is at 110 Mt. Auburn St. There is no charge to park there on Sundays, but there are only 42 spaces, so it is likely hit or miss as to whether you will find an open space.

What did Puritans and Native Americans eat in colonial America? What cooking tools did they use, and what did their food taste like? Get answers to these and many other questions at a talk exploring popular recipes from 17th-century New England. From samp to succotash to strawberry cornbread, you'll learn about the meals that kept body and soul together in Massachusetts in the 1600s. Guest lecturer Lori Stokes is a co-author of "The Pleasure of the Taste" recipe book from the Partnership of Historic Bostons. ]

Free with museum admission which is $6.00.


Event by Historic Newton

results.description:
Our December/January Travel Book Club is here! We’ve been reading

"Americanah" by Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie.

Synopsis provided by Amazon:

Ifemelu and Obinze are young and in love when they depart military-ruled Nigeria for the West. Beautiful, self-assured Ifemelu heads for America, where despite her academic success, she is forced to grapple with what it means to be black for the first time. Quiet, thoughtful Obinze had hoped to join her, but with post-9/11 America closed to him, he instead plunges into a dangerous, undocumented life in London. Fifteen years later, they reunite in a newly democratic Nigeria, and reignite their passion—for each other and for their homeland.

https://www.sheswanderful.com/blog/2015/12/04/wanderful-reads-americanah/

**It's not required that you finish the book by the time we meet, but we hope you do, and come ready to have some interesting discussion about this book. Everyone is welcome!**

Here’s how it works:


• Friday, December 4: Book is introduced. Let’s start reading! Purchase your copy of the book here to support Wanderful.

• Throughout January: Wanderful women discuss the book in person in their local chapters.


Wanderful Boston will be meeting Sunday January 31st at the Capital One 360 Café in Harvard Square at 3:30pm. 

Location: The café is located at 24 JFK Street, Cambridge, MA. 

Remember, if you're driving, parking is free on Sundays! This café is about a 5 minute walk from the Harvard Square T stop on the red line.

Also, each member who attends has to pay $12 per person per calendar year to cover the $144 per year cost to maintain the Jazz Jamming group on the Meetup website. Since the beginning of 2015, we collect the $12 online. This is a one-time payment per calendar year. Thanks very much.

results.description:
Join the oldest established permanent floating Community Walk in Cambridge and Environs.  Join the Community Walkers and walkers from five other meetup groups.   Let's join 20+ others from six other walking groups for:

Since May 2012, there has been a regular walk around Fresh Pond at about an hour before sunset. Frequently, 20-25 walkers turn out for this walk, and you can too. There are a whole bunch of regulars, along with some new people.

We'll go out to dinner at a local pub or chinese restaurant - you can get a decent dinner for under $10.

Frequently, if we eat too much food, we'll go for another walk.

Come see why this walk is so popular. It's at a great time, the people are friendly, the parking is free -- no permit parking in Cambridge on Sunday, so you can park on Huron or Aberdeen Ave.

You can get there by T easily from Harvard Square, take the 71 OR 73 bus to Aberdeen Ave, then walk to the other end of Aberdeen Ave, and you'll see us there. We'll be next to the bridge, on the pond side of Huron Ave,at the intersection of Aberdeen Ave.

If you're late, and we've already started, start walking counter-clockwise. We'll be walking clockwise, so we'll surely bump into each other. We're the large group of vigorously chatting walkers.

Hope to see you there.

Shangri La is located at 149 Belmont Street, Belmont - please let the host know if you're coming, so we can get the right sized table.

venue.name: Panera Bread - Downstairs

results.description:
Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

WHAT: ASL Weekly Social
WHEN: EVERY SUNDAY 
TIME: 4:00-6:00PM
WHO: ANYONE is welcome to come by and have a conversation in ASL
WHY: To socialize, have fun, and enjoy chatting in ASL
WHERE:  Panera Bread in Porter Square Shopping Center

NOTE: Every once a while, the location may change. PLEASE look on the website each week for confirmation. THANKS!


To get to the Meetup, take the RED LINE stop OUTBOUND TO ALEWIFE, and stop at PORTER SQ. Panera Bread is right next to Dunkin Donuts. If you're driving, you can park on the street for free on Sundays!

Anyone who loves ASL is welcome to come and be part of the fun! We want to warmly extend an invitation to Deaf people or others fluent/skilled in the language (CODAs for example) to join our group.

This is an easy-going, casual, ASL get-together to meet people who enjoy American Sign Language, who want to brush up on their signing skills, and want to learn more ASL by using it as often as possible.

We strive to have a good time and communicate without using voices. If we need to, we draw or write what we don't know how to sign, and if lots of folks show up, we split up into small groups and mix and mingle, so we can actually see one another clearly, face-to-face and get a good conversation going.

Don't be afraid or shy if you're not "perfect" at ASL, because being "perfect" is not the point of this group. No one expects that everyone will be at the same level, and none of us mind slowing down or repeating what we have signed so that everyone understands.

We all laugh WITH one another as we fumble along, mess things up, and start over again. This isn't an ASL class, since none of us are certified ASL teachers, so there's really no pressure or expectation--other than that we all use ASL to communicate. We all learn from one another!

IF you've taken an ASL/Sign Language class before (or have had exposure to someone who uses the language) and know the basics (alphabet, numbers 1-20, and even a small vocabulary of signs ), then join us to get your fingers, hands, face and body moving, ASL-style!

IF you haven't taken an ASL class, or don't know the basics, don't be discouraged ... you can come along anyway and learn by watching, and gradually, participating. We have lots of resources that we can suggest for learning ASL from a qualified teacher or authentic source, such as books, online classes, and local classes at various locations near Boston.

If you can, "officially" RSVP, even if the RSVP is "No," so that we know who is definitely going to come.

It will be great to see folks!

Sean
results.how_to_find_us: We will be there signing our beautiful language to inspire all of you!

This month's book is "Becoming Nicole: The Transformation of an American Family" by Amy Ellis Nutt. "The inspiring true story of a transgender girl, her identical twin brother, and an ordinary American family’s extraordinary journey to understand, nurture, and celebrate the uniqueness in us all, from the Pulitzer Prize–winning science reporter for The Washington Post."

Books of interest that we've discussed reading in the future include: H is for Hawk by Helen MacDonald; The Boston Girl by Anita Diamant; Fates and Furies by Lauren Groff; etc. 

Due to seating limitations, we unfortunately have to limit the group to 12 people. If your plans change, it would be greatly appreciated if you update your RSVP in case anyone waitlists. Thanks!
results.name: January Book Club - Becoming Nicole

results.description:
Give yourself the gift of relaxation and rejuvenation with a wonderful 90 minute gentle yoga and meditation class.

True relaxation is experienced by the body and mind when little or no energy is consumed. It is Nature's way of recharging. Since every action, conscious or unconscious, uses stored energy, relaxation is necessary for good health and peace of mind. Without proper relaxation the body and mind become overworked and inefficient.

When the mind is constantly bombarded by stimuli, it becomes overloaded and exhausted. We may be unaware that we are doing it, but by thinking and worrying we are using up tremendous amounts of energy. The tension put on the mind by worries can use more energy than physical work.

Yoga retrains the body to relax and can calm the mind which leads to inner peace.

This class is for beginners and experienced yogi's.  Chairs are available for those who may need to sit during this class.  Please bring your own yoga mat, water and a blanket or pillow for meditation.
results.name: Gentle Yoga & Meditation - 90 minute class

results.description:
Join other single professionals for an early evening happy hour, topped off with about* 7-10 rounds of "mini-dates." You'll meet each member of the opposite sex for 5-7 minutes each (depending on the size of the event), turn in your dating card and then we'll send you the contact info of your mutual matches 48 hours later. On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$24 (MUST register with code ATWYS- codes can not be applied after registration)

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: 

http://atwys2016bostonspeeddating.eventbrite.com

(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS. NO EXCEPTIONS.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.
results.name: Speeddating Ages 39-52--SOLD OUT FOR WOMEN

results.description:
This is an ongoing weekly (donation only) class for anyone, offering experiential practice in meditation, along with an opportunity to be among others interested in deepening spiritutual practices.  The class provides you with a felt sense of your own divinity; your Higher Self. The meditation, based on Kriya practices,  is partly guided, partly silent. In the guided part we open up to the flow of golden light and energy that is always pouring down to our body/mind/heart and being. Accessing that flow and inviting it to fill us brings a profound level of openness, while washing away limiting thoughts, feelings and beliefs. This higher vibration of unconditional love serves to open our consciousness to new levels of peace, joy and awakening. Bringing the flow of light into the body/mind/heart means we more consciously embody our Light Being, so we are more present, happy, forgiving, peaceful and joyful while in the world.
   After the guided portion we spend time in peaceful silence.  Whether you are an experienced meditator or a beginner, you will love the sweetness and powerful energies of this group. At the end of the class we make time for questions or sharing.  Group meditation is powerful, and it's refreshing to be among fellow travelers!
   Judy also teaches the Sound and Light meditation; a way for you to draw your senses inward to open your spiritual eye and to hear the sounds of your chakras. 
   This practice is non-denominational, appropriate for anyone. 
   Held in a lovely healing space, just walking in will bring you instant peace.  All are welcome.
    You may also want to check out my other Meetup, for a variety of spiritual programs:  http://www.meetup.com/Evolving-Beings/

results.description:
The Ultimate Speed Dating Experience is an experience like no other aimed at bringing Professionals of Color singles in the city of Boston and surrounding areas together and possibly making a great match! Come have some fun, food, and drinks while meeting new people, networking, and possibly finding a special someone! Don't be shy! HOW SPEED DATING WORKS:

Register for an event. Advance registration is required.
Gather with several professional singles all in one location.
Dating begins. Have several one-on-one conversations that last between 5 - 7 minutes each.
Conversations are comfortable and safe, since participants don't ask each other for contact information.
When you meet someone you want to see again, write their name and ID number on your Dating Card.
After the event, hand in your date card with the names of the people you would like to meet again.

IT'S FUN!
​ Professionals of Color in the City events are fun and exciting. There is typically a bar and a room full of single people who want to meet YOU! Feel the energy in the room increase as everyone starts meeting lots of new people.

Tired of the usual bar scene and stale dating? IT'S SAFE!

At The Ultimate Professionals of Color SPEED DATING Experience events, the conversations are comfortable and safe because nobody is allowed to ask for your last name, contact information, or for a date.

After each mini date, attendees indicate on their date cards whom they would like to meet again. If both of you, enter each others names, we then provide the contact information so you can arrange a 2nd date.

REGISTER TODAY! To experience an experience like no other! TICKETS AVAILABLE ON EVENTBRITE

http://speeddatingexperience.eventbrite.com

DISCLAIMER: You DO NOT have to be of color to attend this event but you DO have to have interest in men or women of color.
results.name: The Ultimate Professionals of Color In the City SPEED DATING Experience

results.description:
“There is something memorable in the experience to be had by going to a fair ground that stands at the edge of a Middle Western town on a night after the annual fair has been held. The sensation is one never to be forgotten. On all sides are ghosts, not of the dead, but of living people. Here, during the day just passed, have come the people pouring in from the town and the country around. Farmers with their wives and children and all the people from the hundreds of little frame houses have gathered within these board walls. Young girls have laughed and men with beards have talked of the affairs of their lives. The place has been filled to overflowing with life. It has itched and squirmed with life and now it is night and the life has all gone away. The silence is almost terrifying. One conceals oneself standing silently beside the trunk of a tree and what there is of a reflective tendency in his nature is intensified. One shudders at the thought of the meaningless of life while at the same instant, and if the people of the town are his people, one loves life so intensely that tears come into the eyes.” --from Winesburg, Ohio

Winesburg, Ohio: A Group of Tales of Ohio Small-Town Life is a 1919 short story cycle by Sherwood Anderson. The work is structured around the life of protagonist George Willard, from the time he was a child to his growing independence and ultimate abandonment of Winesburg. It is set in the fictional town of Winesburg, Ohio, which is based loosely on the author's childhood memories of Clyde, Ohio.  Known as one of the earliest works of Modernist literature, its influence on early 20th century American literature and beyond was profound.
results.name: Anderson: Winesburg, Ohio

results.description:
We'll follow up on the current events meetup by getting together to write personal letters or emails to politicians or media outlets. 


At an event not long ago, a politician said one personal email or letter carries more weight than one that uses the same words as other emails/letters (as with a big campaign).


We'll bring some topics and ideas, and you can bring yours.  We'll help one another brainstorm, we'll spend time writing, and we'll give feedback to one another before sending off what we wrote.

Feel free to suggest topics in the comments section.

Accessibility Information: Community Change, Inc. is wheelchair accessible with the following limitations.  The door to the building is heavy and does not have a button to open it. The elevator doors are slightly more than 30 inches wide.  The fourth floor bathrooms are not wheelchair accessible, but the first floor bathroom is.  Please let us know your needs so we can help make the event accessible for you.


Note: We welcome intrepid winter bike riders, though there are not many good spots for parking bikes, and bicycles are prohibited in the building.  We apologize for the inconvenience.
results.name: Writing together for change!

results.description:
Join other single professionals for an early evening happy hour, topped off with about* 7-10 rounds of "mini-dates." You'll meet each member of the opposite sex for 5-7 minutes each (depending on the size of the event), turn in your dating card and then we'll send you the contact info of your mutual matches 48 hours later. On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$24 (MUST register with code ATWYS- codes can not be applied after registration)

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: 

http://atwys2016bostonspeeddating.eventbrite.com

(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS. NO EXCEPTIONS.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.

results.description:
{Because of high demand and the limits of our tele seminar software, this event is now closed to new RSVPs. It will be repeated on Mon February 29.  Please consider joining us then.
- - > http://www.meetup.com/Personal-Growth-Network/events/228236881/

This introduction will orient PGN members to the purpose, capabilities, and power of the Personal Growth Network.  

The Personal Growth Network is a first-of-its-kind meta-organizer, bringing together diverse personal growth and positive psychology tools and techniques that are designed to help generally healthy people create greater joy and more success in all parts of their life.  Members can try out, learn, and practice numerous approaches; they can select some for more in-depth study and application; they can practice, support, and share a particular method with other members; and they can return to PGN to explore other approaches or to work on other parts of their life.  

PGN is also a community of like-hearted people who share an important, but not widely distributed, combination of values and characteristics (e.g., curiosity, willingness to learn, willingness to change habits) around consciously and proactively crafting a life well-lived.  For people with this important combination of characteristics, engaging with other members of the community can be fascinating, supportive, and affirming.

And finally, PGN is a toolbox with which members can create successful events.  Members can create workshops, practice groups, and social events through which they can share their journey, their gifts, their joy, their successes, their vision, and their interests.

Given the enormous ambition and power of the Personal Growth Network, and its rapid growth, it is easy to feel a little overwhelmed at first, so we will be offering some "How-To" guides to maximize your utilization of the Personal Growth Network for whatever your life goals may be.  This is the first of those guides, and is a prerequisite for any other guide (including those designed for leaders and for hosts.)

This guide will cover: 

- The Inspiration for PGN
- For Whom is PGN Designed
- How PGN Tries to Help You Live Life Better
- PGN's Purpose, Goals, Methods, Organization
- Finding Your Way Around PGN
- Maximizing Your Benefit on PGN
- Heartbeat Salons: Your Local Communities
- Becoming an Active Member of the Community
- Becoming a Leader in the Community

I will also try to address any specific questions that you post below.

There is no prerequisite to take this How-To, however, this orientation is required for more advanced How-Tos, including 

Mar 13: Creating an Event on PGN
Mar 31: Customizing PGN to You

Please RSVP and the tele-seminar information will be sent to you...

results.description:
Players,

This round robin will be run by David Huie.

We'll run 3 - 40 minute sessions of doubles play with the teams being mixed up after each session.

The event could be mixed doubles or all-ladies doubles or all-men's doubles. It will really depend on who enrolls week to week.   It's all about playing 2 hours straight of doubles tennis.

• New pricing structure because we're being charged more for the courts.

• $24 for the last sign-ups.


If you want to purchase 5 Round Robins you can pay $105 (Save yourself $15 from full price) in cash at any of the events.


YOU HAVE TO RSVP to guarantee your spot in the Round Robin, we can't guarantee walk-ins a spot due to potential court limitations.

*Please understand that we have a zero tolerance for no-shows. If you say you are attending and no-show you won't be eligible to commit for future round robins.

results.description:
It’s Back! The 2016 second season of Liquid Courage Comedy Club at Somerville Brewing.
Professional Comedians on Tap!
Hosted by CJ Browne

The comedy club experience is called the Liquid Courage Comedy Club at Somerville Brewing Company. The brewery and destination-taproom, which opened in April of 2105, opens Sunday nights as a showcase style stand-up comedy club open to the public 21+ Free Entrance before 8:30PM with a $5 cover charge after 8:30pm.

Guests are able to order charcuterie boards, dinner and pints during, before and after the show. With a Sunday night show time of 9PM there is ample free parking is available. Arrive early for the best seats!

Season 2, the 2016 dates are as follows: January 10, 17 24 and 31. February: 7, 14 (Valentine’s Show!) 21 and 28. March 3, 6, 13 20 and 27 (The Jewish Show!)
Past performers at the LIQUID COURAGE Comedy club have been seen on The Last Comic Standing, Comedy Central, Netflix, and Adult Swim. Headliners like Mqy Kaplan graced the stage in season 1 and you’re in for some epic shows in Season 2!

meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
meta.title: Meetup Open Events v2
